author: Undine-XV  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Feb 24, 2008 9:09 pm Gender: Male
title: Episodes with uncontrollable vision, nausea, dizziness, etc.
content: Hello,  I am a 17 year old male. For a while now, I've been having episodes where, out of nowhere, my vision will tip on it's side and then attempt to right itself. It's hard to describe- picture a plank of the wood floating in the ocean. A wave goes underneath the wood, and it rocks- my vision does the same thing, only much much quicker, and repeatedly.  If I attempt to stand, I feel sick to my stomach- I can only stand for a few moments before I fall to the ground. My head is also in pain during these episodes. My vision rights itself after a few minutes, but for about an hour afterward, if I stand my vision swoons and I feel sick again. I must remain laying down. These episodes happen once every month or so, and I may be doing anything at the time. As well as this, I've been experiencing fake memories- or perhaps they aren't, and someone else has just forgotten, but if the events really never did happen, I thought it would be relevant to add. Also, which may also be completely unrelated, I've been experiencing headaches more frequently- once about every two to three days. Do you believe these symptoms could be connected? And, more importantly, do you believe the first symptom may be something serious? I would ask a family member to take me to see a local doctor, but they try to brush everything off as either a cold or growing pains. Anyway... any assistance that you could give would be immensely appreciated, and you'd have my gratitude. Thank you very much for your time.
posted_time: Post  by Undine-XV » Sun Feb 24, 2008 9:20 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Episodes with uncontrollable vision, nausea, dizziness, etc.
content: Hello -  At first I was really perplexed by your symptoms (and if I'm wrong, then I'm still perplexed) but then I realized you could be describing violent vertigo. The description is the way most people would put it, but the bottom line is the same, and amounts to feeling like being on a rocking boat or that the room is spinning or has flipped on its side. I could be wrong, but this would be the first suspicion. There is a very simple  neurological test ("follow my finger") which a doctor or nurse can do to check for nystagmus (abnormal eye movement associated with these episodes) and which can actually trigger the phenomenon in some people. A provocative test (if you decide to try this, don't do it alone) is to lie with your head hanging off the end of a bed, then turn your head one way and then the other. If it is benign positional vertigo (or Menier's disease, which causes the same symptom, but often with more nausea as you've described) you may not make it past hanging your head over the end of the bed, and definitely moving the head once to the side should set it off. If this is the case, it is BPV or Menier's both of which involved a problem with the inner ear and eyes' balance interaction. There are simple medications which can usually control the symptoms effectively.   If I'm totally wrong in my connecting of the dots, please let me know. Otherwise, follow up with us here and let us know if there's anything new or if you've found you do, in fact, have BPV.   At any rate, this is not something that ought to be blown off -- by you or by a doctor, and I strongly suggest seeing one, even if you decide to test yourself for BPV and find it brings on the symptoms. The headaches could indicate an inner ear infection or other problem inside the head that could be more serious than simple  vertigo.  Best of luck to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: moderate headaches in 11 yr old boy after exercise
content: Hello -   While in all  probability, like most headaches, this problem is a very benign thing, it might be worth at the very least bringing it to the attention of a pediatrician, since it seems to be related to exertion, and this  could possibly due to an abnormal increase in blood pressure (which would suggest a possible adrenal problem) or the remote possibility of an arterial malformation between the brain and skull. While either possibility is remote, the complaint is unusual enough to at least warrant bringing it to the attention of a doctor.  Since you brought it here you probably do have some concern, and that's  very responsible of you.   Please do follow up with us on this.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: Re: constant pain on back of my head
content: Hi nssc82, Have you had any labwork done to evaluate for electrolyte abnormalities? In some cases an abnormal sodium level (low sodium/hyponatremia) will produce symptoms of a severe stabbing pain or headache located in the back of the head, nausea/vomiting, weakness, fatigue, confusion etc. I of course am not implying that this is the causative factor for your symptoms however if you have not had any lab studies completed I would suggest that you discuss this matter with your physician. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: Re: stabbing pain ion right side of head
content: Hi,  I would strongly discourage going for your tylenol every morning you get up. All medicines have side effects and getting into a habit of constant painkiller is never a good thing.  I suggest you get in touch with your primary care physician and get  a general health check up incliding Pulse, BP, general and systemic examination, routine blood and urine work up and any Xrays that might be indicated.  This will point to the reason of your pounding headaches, dizziness etc. Generally your kind of headahes are seen in people who have developed a recent high BP. On the other hand some gas, hyperacidity and dyspepsia can also be a known but unrecognized cause.  Take care,   Apurva

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: Re: Headache, Poor Vision, Confusion, and Fatigue
content: Hi,  You feel that lately the acuity of your vision has gone down. At your age it could mean you have developed refractory error that is to say you have got numbers. Get your eye tested and if your optometrist says so, get glasses done.   Suppose you have numbers and you are not wearing glasses, it may give you headaches. On the other hand headaches at your age could be due to tension, stress, migrain, vascular headaches, cluster headaches, and lastly acidity. All these causes of headaches ate benign and can be easily controlled with some proper diagnosis and treatment by your GP.   Your constant feeling of fatigue, sleepiness etc may have its origins in some exogenous or endogenous depression. Try to find out what is bothering you either at work or at home. But first you must get a routine health check up to rule out any specific disease, ask your GP about this.  Take care,  Apurva

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Sever headaches and blackouts
content: Hello, To have a rare occurrence of fainting or blacking out is quite normal and usually does not require follow-up.  If it happens frequently or you are "out" more than a few seconds, it should be checked out with a doctor.    It is true that testing can run up huge bills but if you let the doctor know your situation, I'm sure they can do only the truly necessary testing to be sure you are not in danger from something serious - even if you don't actually have an answer for why it occurs.  Many times we still don't know even after extensive testing because some disorders can be quite evasive to diagnosis and we have to just wait and watch, realizing that some things really are just part of a person's makeup.  But, until we rule out possible problems we can't be confident about it.  Check your community - perhaps call a local hospital or health department to find out if they have any low cost clinics with sliding fee scales.  Or, when making an appointment ask if they offer discounts on visits for cash-paying, non-insured patients.  Also, keep in mind that if you had insurance you would have been paying monthly copays.  Sometimes one visit to the doctor is still less cost than you would have paid in the previous year had you had coverage with copays and/or deductibles besides the premiums.  And, start a health savings account with a little money put aside for such things as this in the future.  If you don't start now you will always be in this dilemma, but putting aside a little while you are well can add up quickly to cover such things as the occasional office visit.  I understand how frustrating this is and insurance certainly is important, especially when serious illness is involved, but it is still not free so you have to keep these things in perspective.  Good luck.

author: mta41  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sat Jan 05, 2008 9:56 pm
title: Experiencing aura, but no headache/migraine?
content: I've already tried reading about migraines and different types of headaches as well as looking through the forum. However, some of what i'm experiencing don't match. So i'm hoping someone might be able to help here.   I'm a 17 year old female and have had headaches since grade 8 although i never really paid attention to them until the last few years. My headaches usually occur on the left side of my head and may be accompanied by a stabbing pain in my left eye. Sometimes the headaches happen around my left eyebrow area. What really bothers me is that sometimes I see flashing lights in different shapes and sizes and they usually last about 30mins (sometimes only a few minutes). Once it occurs, I won't be able to get anywork done since it becomes difficult to read and write (can't judge distance). It used to happen more often (about once or twice per month), then less often (once a few months), but now they're occuring more often again. Usually it only happens in my left eye, but there have been some cases where it happens in both my eyes. I researched this and found out that it's called aura...due to migraines. However, my "aura's" aren't usually accompanied by headaches. I don't think I have migraines either since i don't experience any nausea and I don't have headaches bad enough that it will land me in bed.   I did go see a doctor at my university and she said that she doesn't think I have migraines either since my headaches aren't bad enough. She made an appointment for me to see an ophthalmologist, but I had class that day so I couldn't make it to the appointment.   What can I do to get rid of the flashing lights (It makes studying and concentrating in lectures difficult)? And if they're not caused by migraines, what else can they be caused by? Also, since sometimes my headaches are accompanied by a stabbing type of pain in my left eye, should I be concerned about this?
posted_time: Post  by mta41 » Sat Jan 05, 2008 10:39 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Experiencing aura, but no headache/migraine?
content: Hello, I think seeing an eye doctor would be an obvious and easy thing to do to find out if there is any concern there.  Flashing lights usually do not indicate any serious eye problem. If a large number develop or if they seem to be much worse over a period of time, an examination by an ophthalmologist is recommended.  Also, if you see "floaters" or blacking out of some of your vision in addition to the lights, this might be a more serious eye condition such as retinal detachment so you would not want to delay.    It is also possible you have a mild form of migraine.  Each person responds differently and they don't all get the same symptoms for any disorder.  Ruling out eye problems is definitely the place to start.  You may need to see a neurologist if it continues.    Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Persistent headache worse with orgasm, swollen eye
content: Hello, There are many causes of headaches - the most common are stress related, allergy or sinus problems, migraines and even high blood pressure.  Sex headaches, as with orgasm, are also fairly common.  Some people experience them in clusters - where they occur for a few times, then it may be weeks or months before another cluster occurs.  Sometimes it is related to tightening of muscles which can occur with sexual activity.  An increase of blood pressure can cause the cerebral blood vessels to dilate, resulting in acute headache.  Low blood pressure, anemia, sinus infections, birth control pills have also been associated with sexual headaches.  If the headache is most pronounced with orgasm itself, you might try stopping activity before orgasm.  This would provide more information on the situation.  This is not usually anything serious but it's always good to consult with a doctor to be sure.  Worrying will probably make it worse so peace of mind can be worth a lot.    The eye problem sounds like it could be pinkeye or allergy-related.  You may need antibiotic drops in case it is a bacterial infection.  Some people get relief with eye drops for allergies.    Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: persistent headache
content: Hello, Your doctor is probably right that it is the result of your injury.  You may want to try some alternative pain therapy such as acupuncture if nothing else is helping.  If the headaches are migraines, as you said, you may benefit from medications specifically for that.  Did your doctor prescribe something for that, as opposed to narcotic pain relievers?    Headaches can be one of the most frustrating problems for people because they sometimes come and go for years without a clear cause or effective treatment.  It is believed there may be a hormonal connection since women get migraines much more frequently than men.  But, there is nothing that is a sure cure.    You may also benefit from chiropractic care since this may be spine-related.  I would at least explore that avenue if I were you.    Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Headache, Dizzy & Heart Problems
content: Hello, Yes, it is possible that your symptoms are related.  I would suggest seeing your doctor or cardiologist.  Visual disturbance can be a sign of complications but could also be an independent problem so an eye exam might also be a good idea and perhaps this would be the first thing to try.  Insurance benefits for vision are not typically that great and cost of an exam is usually reasonable so I would do that but still follow up with your doctor if the symptoms continue, get worse or you just sense that things aren't as they should be.    Good luck.

These vivid dreams lead to mild to medium head-ache in the middle part of my head and I do not feel fresh the whole day. Similar happens in the afternoon, when I try to take another nap. posted_time: Post  by rajgj » Sat Jan 05, 2008 12:54 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Morning headache due to dreams
content: Hello, If the headaches are due to the dreams, as you suggest, you might try a sleeping aid because sometimes these medications disrupt your brain wave patterns, affecting the amount of dreaming you do.  I am not suggesting this as a long-term thing but as a trial to see if it alters the REM, delta wave and other brain waves that might make a difference.  Talk to your doctor for a recommendation or prescription.    Afternoon naps often leave a person feeling worse than before they slept so it is recommended that if you do nap, don't do it for more than about 15 or 20 minutes.  Again, this is related to the brain wave patterns.  You could also try relaxation exercises, meditation or yoga before retiring at night.   Changing your current routine could also affect your sleep.  There are also sleep clinics where any type of sleep disturbance can be studied and sometimes there are treatments that can help.  Good luck with this very frustrating problem.

author: jayme  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Feb 27, 2008 9:19 pm Gender: Female
title: Please relieve the pressure in my head!
content: I am writing today to see if someone can help me find out what is wrong with me.  I have a pressure in the back of my head (from ear to ear, and the top of my head to my shoulders.)  Ok Here is a little history on what has been going on with my health. 1 year ago I had an incident where I passed out cold for a matter of moments, my friends where there to get me up and give me some orange juice.  From that day on I have never been the same!  After I fully passed out that one time for the next couple of months I would be driving down the road and have a major sensation that I was going to pass out again, I would have to call someone to let them know where I was just make sure I wasnt going to die. (These are the things going thru my head).    SO I saw the family doctor and gave them every single one of my symtoms.  Also at this time I was having migraines very often.  So I did all the blood work with the family doctor and then she referred me to a Cardiologist, when her we did an EKG and that came back perfectly normal.  So then we moved onto the Neurologist! She had blood work done, MRIs of my head and spine with and without contrast, and an EEG, and you guessed it everything came back fine. She worked with me on the migraines mostly, gave me meds for them and I started to see a chiropractor at the same time and that did wonders for the migraines.  While I was working with the neurologist we came across some blood work that said I was positive for Lymes Disease. My symptomes included being overly tired, very moody at times, fainting sensations when i would do anything strenuous, and this pressure in the back of my head that feels like someone has placed a balloon at the top of my spine into my head and just blows it up whenever they feel like it. So to be very aggressive I started on the antibiotics the same day. I did a 21 day cycle of an antibiotic and this little miracle drug did the trick for the most part.  I still had mild anxiety about there being something else wrong with me that noone was catching.  But I was able to talk myself down with that one.   So then I was fine for about 2 months, not perfect but better.  Then 6 days ago I started to feel a little strange again, so I have tried to contact my neurologist again to do some more blood work to see if anything has changed. 3 days ago while I was at work I had another almost fainting incident and then an anxiety attack and had to be carried out of work. I have this god aweful pressure in the back of my head.  There is nothing I can do to make it better not a position a medicine nothing. My mind races with all the things that could be wrong and it makes the anxiety so much worse.  I have to take a Xanax to sleep and I am afraid of getting addicted...  Someone please help me cause I feel like I am going insane cause everyone says there is nothing wrong on paper, but I believe the total opposite.  Symptoms: *Extreme pressure in the back of my head from ear to ear and shoulders to top of the head. *Headaches from pressure (not migraines) *Random shooting pains thru head and stomach *Food goes in and out very quickly *Anxiety/ Panic * Sleeplessness due to anxiety *Overly tired *Abdominal pain *Overly tired

The pain is always on one side of my head…and feels the worst in the back of my eye and makes it hard to keep that eye open while I feel the pain. Is this something I should see a doctor for? Do you know what the cause could be? Anything helps..thanks :)
posted_time: Post  by jenlokk » Sun Feb 24, 2008 2:44 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Short stabbing headaches..
content: Hello Jenlokk,  The location and intensity of pain you are describing fits with a type of headache called a cluster headache.  This type of headache typically does not come and go so quickly, though.  It is a variation of a migraine that often will recur around the same time of day for several days then go away, as if they occur in clusters.  This may also be a variation of a tension headache from some eye strain.  It is less likely but may be worth having your vision evaluated also.  Look for any causes of eye strain also, such as viewing a computer monitor for extended periods of time.  If these persist is it worth having your doctor evaluate this.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Headache (back of head) and Neck Pain for 2 weeks
content: Hello Jtrowe,  The description of your pain is very consistent with neck tension as the nurse practitioner suspected.  This can be triggered by wearing heavy back packs, etc.; however, it may also be caused by problems with posture, etc.  You may want to try some neck relaxation techniques such as massage to help relieve this pain.  Using the heat pack, etc. is also an appropriate treatment.  Take a look at your posture and make sure it is straight.  Also, it would be good to look at your work area (desk, chair, etc.) to see if these are causing you to be in a position that is causing some increased neck pressure.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Heat Exhaustion and Headaches
content: Hi Dangerousl33,  Heat exhaustion and heat stroke can be quite dangerous.  Most likely, though, at this point you'll be OK.  I would suggest you see a doctor for an evaluation to check everything out. Occassionally there can be some ongoing electrolyte issues, etc. that can occur with heat stroke.  Staying well hydrated will help as well.  It may take you several days to fully recover from this.   Until then you should probably be self limited in your activity level.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: migraine or something else..
content: Hello Angel242,  Headaches commonly will follow neck trauma from car accidents.  In particular, if a person has a history of headaches or migraines, the resulting neck trauma can worsen the occurrences and make them more common.  Sometimes some physical therapy can help with this.  Occasionally, what happens is that there is some slight malalignment of the neck due to the accident that then causes the muscles to tighten up to protect the area.  This, in turn, leads to the headaches.  Physical therapy can help loosen the muscles and ease the tension in the neck.  With your other associated issues such as the memory problems these headaches may represent complex migraines or basilar artery migraines (migraines due to spasming of the basilar artery in the back are of the neck/brain).  I would suggest you see your primary care doctor or neurologist again to see about using a prophylactic medication to help prevent you from getting so many headaches.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Head pain in back of head
content: Hello Virginiagal46,  I apologize for the delay in responding.  By now I suspect your pain has resolved.  However, for informational benefit, your pain may be due to a viral infection or an atypical bacteria infection (such as mycoplasma, the cause of atypical or "walking" pneumonia).  These infections commonly cause chest tightness and shortness of breath.  They, in particular certain viruses, can also cause muscle inflammation of the neck muscles.  In some cases, they can also cause meningitis, which can cause neck pain and stiffness.  If, by chance, you are still having the pain I would strongly recommend you have it evaluated by your doctor.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: My Wife has eye pain
content: Hi Stephan,  There are several causes of eye pain.  One of the more common causes is a migraine headache.  This type of pain would be unlikely to come and go quickly, though.  I'm not certain but based on your description I am presuming that these pains are relatively brief.  There may be a component of eye strain causing these pains as well.  This can still happen with a normal ophthalmologic exam.    Transient ischemic attacks (TIA's), or "mini-strokes" can cause eye problems but I would not expect this to be such a chronic issue with no other symptoms.  It's possible but unlikely.  If these pains continue I would recommend that your wife see a neurologist for further evaluation.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: mysterious painful bump on the back of the head
content: Hi Ashme,  There are a few possibilities.  You may be feeling an inflamed lymph node.  The other possibility is that a small blood vessel broke leading to the bump (basically a blood clot under the skin called a hematoma).  Hematomas themselves are usually not painful but the area can hurt because usually there was some trauma that caused the hematoma to form.  If this persists I would suggest you see your doctor.  Occasionally, lymph nodes or hematomas can become infected and need antibiotics to help them clear up.  Best wishes.

content: Hi Shaz29,  Sorry for the deletion of your first post.  We had some technical difficulties.    You are correct that using contrast is better for detecting a tumor or aneurysm. author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Large tumors will still be picked up by CT scans without contrast.  Aneurysms will be much more difficult to see without contrast, as will small tumors.  If there is concern for these, a contrast CT or contrast MRI really is superior to a non-contrast study.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: This is true if the tumor or aneurysm is large enough.  Small tumors can be missed on non-contrast CT scan.  Aneurysms are going to be much harder to see without contrast because they tend not to be large enough to cause mass effects and push things around.  I would agree that, based on what you've described, your headaches sound like tension-type headaches.  Bes wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Headache
content: Hello, My guess is that you are having tension headaches, which are the most common type.  Stress is believed to be a primary cause of these.  You may have more luck treating this if you combine the pain reliever (in sufficient dosage to do the job, so go with the maximum allowed on the package) and some stress reduction.  People have been successful with relaxation exercises or even just taking a 20 minute nap.  This seems to give the best outcome - better than either activity alone (medication or rest).  You can also learn some other relaxation techniques such as yoga or visualization.    We don't actually know the cause of the most common headaches but if they persist, you should see a doctor to rule out any underlying medical condition.  You do want to be sure your blood pressure is in the range of normal.    Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Mon Dec 17, 2007 4:13 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Megrim,  Complex migraines can have effects other than pain.  It may be that the area your migraine is affecting controls the release of the water regulatory hormones of the body.  You may want to discuss this with a neurologist.  I suspect that really the thing to do is try to treat the migraine to get it to go away and this is not a particularly dangerous issue as long you can keep from getting too dehydrated.  Best wishes.

Mid-November '07 I started getting a flashing dot in one eye. Test showed nothing.  Been crying off and on since Mid-Nov '07 Moved out on my own again, Mid-Nov '07  I get headaches a lot, but as of a week or so ago, it's been worse. I've had three dizzy spells (usually when getting up from what I remember) I get flush and clammy. Tired. Can't sleep well.  My neck is stiff, shoulders hurt, my face is blotchy, my jaw is a little tight, I get the odd spasm in my back (not enough to make me twitch or anything)   Diabetes runs in both sides of my family. My Mom thinks I'm either anemic, have low blood pressure, or it's a blood sugar thing (which would be new for me)  Is this stress... or does it sound like it fits something else? I kind of hope it's something else because I'm really tired/embarassed at unintentionally making myself feel sick here and there (anxiety disorder) I didn't think I was stressed though.  I sometimes feel sick too, but that might just be my worrying about whatever is going on with me.  Sorry to ramble, I just wanted to make sure I didn't forget anything that might be important.   Thank you so much for this forum, and for taking the time to read/reply to the msgs. I think there is something wrong with me - maybe a different deficiency or something, because I haven't felt physically right since Summer of 2005, and now other things are happening as I just mentioned. I hope someone has an idea of what this is. I really want to feel better. This is depressing.  Take care, and Happy Holidays to everyone.  ~ Kimberly

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Kimberly,  Your symptoms may be due to a few different things going on.  The dizziness sounds like you may be a little low on blood volume (dehydrated) or possibly anemic.  You may have a cold virus that is causing all these symptoms (particularly the dizziness, jaw pain, etc) to appear.  You may also be having some exacerbation of your anxiety, etc. making the symptoms worse.  I'd suggest you see your doctor and possibly have some screening labs (complete blood count to look for anemia and also to look for elevations in the white blood cells that may indicate infection).  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Acegolfer7,  Your description of the headache and location are consistent with a tension type headache.  These may also be migraines.  Tension headaches often will occur in the afternoon, can be pounding, and are often located in a headband distribution including the temples and/or back of the head.  Migraine headaches can also occur in the back of the head.  Typically with migraines, light hurts the eyes, sound can hurt the ears, and they may be associated with a sense that the headache is going to occur before it begins.    I would suggest you see your doctor to discuss this if your headaches occur.  It is reasonable to try using a pain medicine such as ibuprofen or tylenol if you have not done this already.  Also, you can look for things that may be triggering your headache, such as certain foods or activities that you are alway doing before the headache starts.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by shaz29 » Thu Nov 15, 2007 7:31 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello, I can understand your concern because any time there is a constant pain such as this, you know something is not right and you want to find out what is causing it, especially when it develops suddenly.  Naturally your mind jumps to the worst case scenario.    Typically an aneurysm will have other symptoms beyond the headache, which is usually described as "the worst pain or headache of my life."  I would be surprised though if you did not also have other neurological symptoms such as visual disturbances, behavior changes, nausea/vomiting, balance problems, fatigue, or stiff neck.  Of course these symptoms can also go along with other conditions, even the labyrinthitis.  The diagnosis of an aneurysm would be verified by a CT scan.  If your headache does not improve soon, follow up with your doctor.  There are many different types of headaches with a myriad of causes so it may take a while to be sure of the cause of yours.  Hopefully you will get some relief soon.    Talk to your doctor about certain maneuvers or exercises (Brandt and Daroff exercises and Epley maneuver) that may speed your recovery from the labyrinthitis.  There are also some home remedies that may help.  Reduce salt and sugar intake, avoid chocolate, caffeine, alcohol and tobacco.  Lie still in a comfortable position, on your side (flat).  There are medications that sometimes help so if the one you have doesn't work, let your doctor know.  If you should have additional symptoms, especially if they seem like stroke symptoms (weakness especially on one side, speech difficulty, extreme and sudden pain, unconsciousness, etc.) get emergency treatment.  Best wishes for a full recovery.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Headache, especially one that comes and goes, can certainly be one of the symptoms of allergies.  But, of course there are many causes of headaches and it would be impossible to say for sure.  If it does not respond to acetaminophen, rest and reasonable food intake (to verify it is not caused by low blood sugar) you should have it evaluated by your doctor.    If it is an allergy-induced headache, you may get relief from an antihistamine and/or decongestant.  Try to record any patterns you notice about the headaches so you can report these to your doctor.  Good luck.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  It would be hard to tell obviously without a careful assessment. To answer your question: headaches that are worse in the morning are commonly depression and hangover headaches. Cluster headache also causes morning headaches but these usually wake the patient from sleep.  Palpitations on the other hand may reflect anything from anxiety to a change in the heart's rate, volume of output, or more commonly, rhythm. Also anything that can lead to a change of rhythm can obviously lead to palpitations - so diseases such as thyrotoxicosis or pheochromocytoma can also lead to this picture. Please understand the limitations of internet communication in assessment of any medical presentation.   More commonly the cause of your symptoms would be something a lot more benign and may even be self limited. I only mention the more alarming causes to convince you that there is no replacement to a proper direct assessment by your doctor.  Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Mon Nov 12, 2007 1:00 pm

author: elthiastar  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Sep 16, 2007 3:57 am
title: What is the standard care for migraines?
content: I'm new here. I'm a 31 y/o female with a strong family history of migraines. My father died this past year from cancer and I've been recently diagnosed with migraines with auras. I also have a history of chronic diarrhea ever since I had my gallbladder removed several years ago, and I manage the diarrhea with cholestyramine 4 gm twice daily. I'm on topamax 75 mg daily, I have prn axert 12.5mg, prn phenergan 25mg, prn lunesta 3 mg, and I take a prenatal vitamin daily due to family hx of MTHFR mutation. (it's just precautionary, I haven't had any blood clots, and my labs have always been ok)  The situation is that I have just finished up a debilitating 10 day migraine, aura with bright lights, dizziness, photophobia, phonophobia, vomiting, diaphoresis, diarrhea, stabbing pains in the eye, tinnitus.  I tried taking axert with no effect, I had some fiornal left over from an old script and took it occasionally just so I could sleep, I took a total of 8 pills over a 7 day period. Phenergan was not effective, and by day 4 I was vomiting uncontrollably.  I was unable to take by cholestyramine due to vomiting. So I went to the family med clinic, recieved IM phenergan/stadol discharged home. To ED the next day for uncontrolled vomiting, recieved IV reglan/decadron one liter of fluids discharged home. Spent next 2 days (weekend) in dark room clutching emesis basin. Then became so weak I could hardly stand and the diarrhea was watery, so back to family med clinic, where I fainted walking back to room. Seen by PA, no labs done, given shot of vistaril, refused pain meds(was told my headache was from "taking too much pain meds), given neurology consult and sent home with a script for phenergan suppositories when I complained oral phenergan wasn't managing the nausea. The pain in my head was so bad that on the way home I was curled into a fetal position and crying. The very next night back to ED because I was vomiting so hard I was having chest pain so bad I could hardly breathe and was sweating. This time my husband was threatened that he would be forcibly removed from the ED for speaking up for me. I was given an  EKG, IV compazine, 1/2 bag fluids, no pain meds and sent home.   Is this standard care for migraines???  I feel like I've been treated like such a low life. I have no history of drug use, no psychiatric history, and now I'm scared to go back to the clinic or ED for anything, But the next nearest clinic that accepts our insurance is over an hour away, and they aren't accepting new patients. I just took my last axert for a migraine a few hours ago, and my insurance won't pay for a refill till next month. I've been out of work for 2 weeks and I don't have $150 to pay for the script out of pocket.  My brother has offered me his meds, but he's on a different triptan, and I'm scared to mix meds.   Any suggestions?

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello there,  Recurring headache in the back of the head (occipital) can occur due to several causes. Cervical (neck) nerve root conditions can lead to pain in the back of the head, neck and may be accompanied by tingling sensation in the neck. It can be diagnosed by a CT scan of the neck vertebrae as well as clinical signs.  Other causes include muscle spasms and tension headache which can occur especially after periods of stress.  If this is a recurring problem, I would suggest you inform your doctor and have it properly assessed.  Good luck and keep this thread updated.

author: butterflyhugzs  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Oct 07, 2007 1:12 pm
title: Do I need an MRI scan?
content: Hello, I really could do with some advice. I have suffered with headaches and migraines for a few years now but the headaches seemed to have increased in frequency. I now can get about three headaches a day; I can normally cope for a while but often have to take pain killers at least once a day. I often wake with a headache in the morning which clears quite quickly. When I get really bad headaches/migraines I can only lie on my left side as the pain is too intense. Walking bending forward and straining make the bad ones worse. I have recently developed blurred vision and weakness down my left side, which have also developed a burning in my leg and nausea I also get terrible neck pain. My doctor seemed concerned and sent me to see a neurologist, as I have CFS and Fibromyalgia he thinks it is probably my illness causing these new symptoms. I am not 100% sure. I also get dizzy, tinnitus, facial pain all down the left side very bad memory. But have had these symptoms for a long time. My doctor recently done tests like getting me to walk on my heals and toes, which I could not do, any idea what that is about? When I saw the neurologist he said he did not think it was a neurological problem. He said it is probably due to the other illness although he did notice the weakness down my left side. I had a 10 minute MRI about 9 months ago but it concentrated on my ear as tinnitus is worse in left ear, this was fine. As the MRI was looking in a certain area would it have picked up if something else was wrong? My doctor seemed to imply he wanted me to have a full brain and maybe body scan but this did not happen, I am in the UK and am an NHS patient but wondered if I should go private and have an MRI scan as I am obviously worried by the amount and severity of the headaches, Is this normal? Should I be worried? Someone mentioned contrast with an MRI scan would this help. Sorry so much information any advice would be helpful. Thank you
posted_time: Post  by butterflyhugzs » Sun Oct 07, 2007 2:06 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Butterflyhugzs,  You have mentioned a few things that make me concerned.  With a past history of migraines it is certainly possible that you are simply having worsening migraines. However, waking up with a headache is very atypical for a migraine since sleep generally relieves it.  Also, migraines do not typically cause weakness.  Given these things I think it would be very appropriate to have an MRI of the head with contrast to look for any possible problems.  Follow up with your doctor is important.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Some people develop vertigo, where you feel like the room is spinning and you could experience nausea, visual disturbance as well as ringing in the ears.  Ear infections can also have a similar effect.  You should seek urgent medical care if you develop double vision, weakness, headache, difficulty speaking, abnormal eye movements, or even acting "not yourself."    There are other causes of lightheadedness and fainting so it is difficult to say what the cause might be.  If this is still going on, I would suggest talking with your doctor about it.    Good luck.

title: Cracking joints, headaches
content: I am actually not sure where to post this comment as it has to do with pain throughout my body.   I've been cracking my joints (knuckles, elbows, knees, neck, back..) for around 18 years. I'm 25 now. I want to stop, but if I don't crack certain areas like my neck, I will start to be in pain. If I don't crack my neck I will develop an intense headache... Is this just a withdrawal effect? Is there a better way to quit than just cold turkey?  Sorry if this wasn't a good place to post this.   Have a great day
posted_time: Post  by HGVCBoy » Tue Sep 25, 2007 10:04 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi HGVCBoy,  There has never been any conclusive evidence that cracking joints causes any distress except for the possibility that some stress over the long term could  subject the tendons and bones to unnatural pressure. Over a long period of time, body tissues do not recover so well from such manipulations. This can create joint pain similar to that of professional athletes after years of repetitive muscle/ligament stress.  The idea that it could cause arthritis has not been substantiated.  It is unlikely that it is causing the headache unless you are just feeling tense due to the desire to "crack" and that tenseness itself is causing headache.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Thu Sep 27, 2007 3:09 pm

The headaches usually do not last terribly long, perhaps 30 minutes to an hour.    We have tried to figure out what is triggering the headaches but we can't seem to find a common cause. She has had headaches at school, at home, during the day, in the evenings,  even during times when she is doing something fun like playing with friends or participating in an acitivity she really enjoys. When a headache starts she will stop whatever she is doing  hold her head and just want to lie down somewhere.   Once the headache is gone, she is back to her old self.  Our daughter is healthy and has had no major health problems.  She doesn not have vision problems. She is not on any medication. We do occasionaly give her childrens Tylenol for pain, but we first wait to see if the headache will go away on its own. She is happy and social, enjoys school and is an overall content child. It is just these headaches that are interupting her life and causing her pain several times a week.  Any thoughts would be greatly appreciated.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi sokan, Minor head injuries that do no alter the neurological state, ie, visual disturbances, changes in pupil reactions, unconsciousness, behavior changes, dizziness, seizure, vomiting, unusual headache, etc., can, generally speaking, be treated at home by application of ice to the bruised area. Any alteration in neurological status or presence of unusual symptoms should always be evaluated by a physician. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

I went to the doctor & they placed me back on paxil, it made me feel worse. i had to stop at the fire station because I was shaking & was having shortness of breath & chest pains.I think I was having another panic attack. They took my blood pressure it was up to 150. I went too the doctor the next day, he told me to get off the paxil & gave me some propranolol & hydroxyzine.I told him about my headaches. They say it is migrane & stress related.  I tried that for a couple of weeks. I still did not feel any better.I no longer take those medications. I had another attack & went to the hospital & they prescribed clonazepam when needed. I am no loger taking that medication either.  All the doctors say I am suffering from anxiety other than that I am healthy. They did a blood tests, thyroid, urine, and whiteblood tests. Everything was normal. They say my blood pressure is normal. The propranolol was to slow my heart down. I have also gotten my eyes checked. Things from a distance have gotten blurred. My left eye seems to be much worse than my right. The doctor says I will need the glasses when I am driving or at night. I am a frequent vistor to the doctors office. I feel like I am losing my mind.  I have had 2 ekgs done. My heart is fine, but my head still feels worse. I also got into an accident ten years ago. I got hit by a car crossing the street. I have a plate on my left checkbone. They had to take a bone from my skull for my fractured cheekbone on the left. They also had to make the incision on the left side of my face. One of the doctors say my headaches might be caused from my nerves where they had surgery.I also still have my anxiety attacks. Please help. Is it just anxiety?  Am I just suffering from tension, cluster, migranes, or chronic headaches or something more?

author: princetonlim  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Aug 12, 2007 9:33 pm
title: Sharp pain during plane descend
content: I am 38 years old, Male. During a flight around 5 years ago, I had an very sharp pain when the plane descends, starting from the top of my left eye, shooting up to the top of my head. I had similiar pain on the flight before, but not as excruciating. I am worried that my blood vessels may burst or get stroke because of that and I didn't fly after that. My question is : 1. will my blood vessels burst or will I get stroke because of that? 2. What can be done before the flight to prevent such sharp pain? 3. What are the risks if I do fly again?
posted_time: Post  by princetonlim » Sun Aug 12, 2007 9:59 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Princetonlim,  I suspect that your pain may have been due to occluded sinuses.  The area you are describing is the area of the frontal sinus.  If the opening was blocked, perhaps due to congestion or sinusitis, the air pressure in the sinus would not be able to adapt to the new air pressure.  This can cause tremendous pain.  This phenomenon is essentially the same as what happens when your ears pop during take off and landing.  Using a decongestant medication prior to take off or landing may help to make sure your nasal passages and sinuses are open to reduce the issues with this.  It is unlikely that you would get a stroke from the pressure changes during landing.  It is possible to develop some blood clots during long flights that could potentially cause a stroke if they were able to bypass the lungs some how (such as through a small opening in the heart called a patent foramen ovale) and get to the brain.  To help prevent these clots from forming it is advisable to get up periodically and walk around during long flights.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Emmalou,  It sounds as if you have a raging cold going on.  There are a few things you can do to help.  The safest is to try using a saline nasal spray to help wash out your nose.    Decongestants with pseudoephedrine are generally considered safe during pregnancy.  Benadryl (diphenhydramine) is also safe.  Use caution when buying over-the-counter cold medicines because they generally have two, three or more medicines in them.    You can also ask the pharmacist at your local medication store to help find a medicine that is safe for you.  Best wishes.  I hope you feel better soon.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Freddie,  Sorry for the delay in answering.  You've probably already made a decision but here's some information for you.  Often for nose trauma, as long as the patient is otherwise OK, there isn't much that is done.  If the nose is fractured it generally will heal on its own.  It would be unusual for the fracture to need surgical repair.    It may also be that the swelling is due to the soft tissue injury which can be significant.  This, too, will generally heal without incident.  If she is otherwise OK, it is probably fine to wait to see her regular doctor.  If she has worsening headaches, mental status changes or nosebleeding that won't stop after 10 minutes of direct pressure she should be seen sooner.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: It is entirely possible that there is no connection between these varied symptoms so you should check out each problem individually.  It will be helpful to try anti-gas medications that you can get over-the-counter to see if you can get that problem under control.  (Gas-X, simethicone, even Mylanta).  That's an easy thing to try and won't do any harm if it doesn't help.  I wonder if your leg problems that are hard to describe might be restless leg syndrome.  You may find that some regular exercises such as daily walks or jogs might help this.  Your doctor may also be able to prescribe something if this seems to be the case.    Headaches can be caused by a myriad of things from foods eaten, allergies, sinus congestion to stress, inadequate sleep, eye problems and many other triggers in between. You should have this evaluated by a family practice doctor or neurologist.  Be sure to describe all your symptoms when you go in.  Good luck.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi LittleBUGer,  Some monitors and some monitor settings are known to produce more eye strain and eye fatigue than others.  It certainly may be that your new settings are causing your  eyes to work harder.  After hours of eye strain, headaches commonly develop.  If you have a human resources department at work they often have people working for them that deal with ergonomic issues to help prevent overuse injuries.    If you are able to modify the settings of your monitor this may also help.  Additionally, it may not be your monitor by itself.  Take a look at the lighting and the rest of the set up at your desk to see if you can arrange things better to minimize eye strain, such as making the monitor eye level, etc.  Best wishes.

The visualized intracerebral vessels demonstrate normal flow voids.  Single non-specific 3mm white matter hyperintensity is noted on Image 15.  Visualized paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells are clear.  There is no MR evidence of acute infarct."  Daily, I take the following medicines (1 each at night): Crestor 20mg, Lotrel 10/20, Zoloft 100mg, Detrol LA 4mg, and Aygestin 5mg.  A month ago, he prescribed Limbitrol 5mg/12.5 mg to see if that would help rid me of the headache.  Today, in addition to all the meds above, he has asked me to take Topamax 25 mg.  Literally, this headache has not left me since January.  It ranges from mild (2-3 on a scale of 1-10) to extreme (over 10, to the point of wanting to go to the emergency room).  I have kept a diary and there is no dicernable pattern of when the headaches ramp up or down.    My bloodwork, all done within the last month is normal with the following exceptions:  Chloride 114 CO2 20 ALK Phosphatase 49 Iron 54 MCV 101.7 % Lymphocytes 13 % Neutrophils 81   Any thoughts of what to ask my doctor to look for? posted_time: Post  by nschmid » Thu May 31, 2007 8:48 am

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Nschmid, I wish I had an opportunity to evaluate you live and in person. The lab results you present are not significantly off, in my experience, to contribute to severe headaches.  If the MRI was negative (as you indicated), then other sources of the problem need to be considered.  I would venture that your primary MD has already considered the medications you are on, and has determined they are not either a contributing factor.  I would like to throw out a thought:  Since these headaches started in Mid-January, and I would assume you have not added any medications to your routine, then I would suggest you consider another source:  Stress.  Have you experienced any increase in life stressors since December?  Has there been any major changes in your personal or business life?  Stress doesn't only have to be negative stress (such as divorce, separation, death of loved ones, job changes, residence changes, etc.) Stress can also be extremely positive ones: getting a great promotion, getting married, getting a new home, etc.  I have a saying:  The body will scream what the mind is unable to vocalize.  A headache is the number one symptom to show up when a person is experiencing abnormal stress.  I suggest your weigh this consideration and see if it may be indeed true for you. If so, then stress-reducing and stress-eliminating strategies are in order.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: You may want to be tested for mononucleosis.  Your description isn't textbook for this but it may cause many of your symptoms.  Mono is caused by a virus called epstein barr virus (EBV).  You may also want to have a general electrolyte panel done.  Some electrolyte abnormalities can cause some of your symptoms as well.  For example, low potassium may contribute to weakness and fatigue.   Many of your symptoms are quite non-specific making it hard to pin them all down on one thing.  I would suggest you have a general evaluation by your doctor to look for any physical exam clues that may help.  Best wishes.

Recently, to help with daily chronic headaches, my doctor prescribed 10 mg of Amitriptyline HCL once a day before bed.  It has helped the headaches VERY much.  However, for the past couple of weeks I have been seeing eye "floaters" or spots.  The only other medication I am on is Birth Control. Could these "floaters" be a side effect of the medication or is it something more serious?  Thank you!
posted_time: Post  by bobcatgirl06 » Mon Apr 30, 2007 4:09 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Amitriptyline can cause some vision issues.  There are other migraine prevention medicines that can be used.  You may want to discuss changing medications with your doctor to see if the spots get better once you're off the amitriptyline.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I do have one suggestion.  It sounds as if your dad has had a pretty thorough work up.  If he has not had one, I would recommend a lumbar puncture to measure the pressure of the spinal fluid (called opening pressure).  If it is elevated this would be consistent with a condition called pseudotumor cerebri.    Pseudotumor can cause tremendous headaches and would not show up on an MRI.  Beyond this, I can't think of much else.  Sometimes it is helpful to keep a headache diary tracking when the headaches occur and what was going on during the time preceding it (what foods were eaten, etc.) to see if there are any triggers that can be avoided.  Best wishes.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Julie,  I hope you have an appointment with your neurologist soon so you can get definitive answers to your questions.  I am sure your regular doctor is not giving you a diagnosis since the results of the MRI really need to be reviewed by a neurologist who can diagnose the problem. Since internet discussion of disease processes are limited, diagnosis of specific problems with serious tones such as you relay, really needs to be done face to face with a specialist. If the results of the MRI are accurate, further differentiating tests may be necessary.  One of the demylenating diseases is MS (multiple sclerosis), and there are treatment options available, and support groups available all over the country. There are diagnostic tests that can either correlate or refute these findings, and the neurologist would be the best one to make the determination which to order for you.  Then, once the root cause is identified, the best treatment plan can be put into place.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Irene, You did not mention how long ago you bumped your head.  I would gather fairly recently from your post.  You also did not mention if you were knocked out when you hit your head, or if you experienced any loss of vision.  I would guess maybe not, so what I will tell you is based on assuming you were not knocked out.  Soft tissue injury anywhere on the body causes the body to swell as a protective mechanism, and it can take a long time - several days even a week or so for the swelling/bruising  to go down.  Did  you try an ice pack? At this phase, a warm compress may actually help better by increasing circulation to the area and allowing the body to reabsorb the swelling.  If you are experiencing any dizziness, or increasing pain it is strongly advisable that you go to the emergency room if you do not have a primary care physician to get it checked out.

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Dear Dan: There could be several reasons for having a headache that doesnt seem to go away and tension is certainly one of them.  One of the reasons most common for forehead types of headaches is sinus infection.  If you press your fingers on the eyebrow area and also just under the eyes next to your nose, is it tender and painful? These are where your sinuses are and an infection in them can cause a long lasting headache.  You certainly do need to see a doctor to evaluate whether it is a sinus infection or something a little more serious.  Tension headaches while they can be along the forehead tend more to be on the sides of the forehead at the temple area and stretch to the back of the head and into the neck where there is a lot of muscle tension contributing to the headache.  A good evaluation by your doctor should be able to determine what is causing your headaches and give you some treatment to relieve them. Best wishes, Carolyn LPN

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Dear Dan: A sinus infection is an infection that requires antibiotics.  While some over the counter medications can relieve some of the discomfort it cannot clear the infection.  Using nasal sprays with a sinus infection can in fact spread the infection further so I would not use them till the infection has cleared.  Warm packs though across the forehead can ease some of the congestion that develops from the infection.  But, you need to be treated by a physician for the infection. Best wishes, Carolyn LPN

title: Immense Pressure when standing
content: Hi,   I am a 25 year old female who has just undergone a disk replacement in my lower spine. But for the past 3 years I have had excrutiating pain and pressure in my head when I stand up or lie down on my side or stomach.  It is such a strange and scary feeling. When I stand up I feel faint, my ears throbe and my vision is disturbed.  I have had MRI's, cortizone injections, radio frequency procedures. Nothing seems to be helping the pain and pressure. PLEASE can some one give me advice to patients with similar symptoms.   I am in agony and don't know whree to turn next.
posted_time: Post  by Giankins » Mon Apr 02, 2007 5:54 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Headaches that are worse with standing are suspicious for "spinal" headaches.  A simplistic view of this is that there is not enough spinal fluid to adequately float the brain so that when one stands the brain is not properly supported.  This causes the brain to pull down on its attachments and causes a tremendous headache.  It is relieved some by being in a position that takes pressure off the brain such as being flat.  Usually this type of headache occurs after a procedure such as an epidural where a small hole is created in the epidural space that can allow spinal fluid to leak out.  In this situation, if nothing is done the headache will usually resolve in 2-3 weeks.  3 years is almost unheard of for this situation.  If, by chance, you have a chronic CSF (cerebrospinal fluid) leak that is not healing you could have this type of headache.  I am not aware of such a condition; however, it is theoretically possible.  Sometimes theories don't translate into reality well, though.  I would recommend you see a neurologist or possibly a neurosurgeon to see if any testing can be done on your CSF pressures or to look for a CSF leak  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Thu Apr 12, 2007 12:29 pm

author: FireGirl127  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Fri Mar 30, 2007 1:48 pm Location: New York
title: Chills, Nausea, Dizziness, Muscle tremors, Weakness
content: I am a 29 year old femaile with a history of migraine headaches. I have had a ceserean section 4 yrs ago along with breast augmentation in '99. There is no history of migraine headaches in my family, however I started getting them since I started taking birth control when I was 18. I just started taking Verapamil and Midrin as prescribed by my neurologist.  Here is my question: The other day I woke up with a migraine and took an Imitrex (previously prescribed) at 8am. It worked and I went about my day at work. Around 12:30pm, I began feeling dizzy and nauseated. I layed down and then began getting muscle spasms in my face and buttocks. I became very weak and couldn't barely talk or move my hands or feet. I then began getting  chills and my blood pressure started to become high 158/106 (usually run 90/60) Pupils became fully dialated. They took me to the hospital via ambulance. The hospital ran CT scans, MRI's, bloodwork, and everything came back ok. They diagnosed me as having a migraine, however I did not have a headache at the time of the incident or after. After this whole episode, I felt exhausted. Do you think it may have been a migraine with the symptoms I had and no headache, or could this be some type of Stroke symptoms. My neurologist is sending me for tests for Stroke. I'm not sure.    Thanks!
posted_time: Post  by FireGirl127 » Fri Mar 30, 2007 2:12 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: It's possible that you had a stroke but I think this is very unlikely.  More likely is that you had an atypical migraine that caused your blood pressure to drop some.  Subsequently, in response to the low blood pressure you likely had a catecholamine surge (the same hormones involved in the fight or flight response).  This would cause your heart to race, your BP to go up and your eyes to dilate.  It is common after such an event to feel tired.  It is also possible that you were experiencing some side effects of the Imitrex.  Imitrex is known to cause nausea/dizziness as well as high blood pressure.  Follow up with your neurologist will be important.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Mon Apr 02, 2007 11:14 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: There are a few possible causes I can think of.  It is possible that you are having a variant of a migraine headache.  These can cause dizziness or feelings of being off balance (dysequillibrium) as well as head pain.  You may also have an inner ear infection although these tend to be severe and cause the room to spin (vertigo), nausea and headaches.  Another possibility is an otolyth or small stone that is lodged in the motion detecting parts of your ear.  This typically will cause vertigo more than a headache.  You may wish to see a neurologist for an evaluation.  They can recommend any specialized testing that you may need and hopefully get you on a treatment to relieve your symptoms.  Best wishes.

title: Sharp Pain & tingles
content: 44yrs old Female No Medication  For the past 3 days I have had severe sharp shooting pains on the top left hand side of my head (generally in the area of where I part my hair), it is not in the one spot, but it has travelled along the parted hairline. The pain has lasted no more than 20 - 30 seconds at a time. My scalp feels very tingly/prickly & for the first two days even the hair folicles were extremly painful if touched. Now on the 3rd day I have not had the sharp pain (head is still a little sensative) but the left side of my face (from under the eye to the bottom of the cheek bone), from the outside of the left nostral to the outer cheek bone has felt numb, but is ok to the touch.  I thought at first it might be shingles but there is no rash & it is not itchy.   thank you for your reply
posted_time: Post  by mareelee » Mon Mar 26, 2007 12:44 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: The areas you are describing are innervated by different nerves.  The scalp is mostly a spinal nerve in the c1-c2 area.  The face sensation is provided by the 2nd branch of the 5th cranial nerve in the area you are experiencing numbness.  It is possible that you had some irritation of your scalp from brushing your hair or possibly pulling it too tight.  It is also possible that you had a little pressure on the nerve somewhere along its course causing your pain.   It is difficult to tie this to your facial symptoms.  The best way I can think of is that you may have had a viral infection causing your initial symptoms that now is producing a post-infectious syndrome.  Occasionally post-viral syndromes can include neurological finding such as you are describing.  I would suggest that you be seen by your doctor to get a full neurological exam and look for any other more subtle involvement of the nervous system.  This may help in providing a diagnosis.  You may need a referral to a neurologist if your symptoms don't improve.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Wed Mar 28, 2007 10:01 pm

My Dr put me on Fioricet, which gave me no relief, as did no OTC medications or Vicodin/Percoset.  It is not a rebound as I do not take a lot of meds back to back. posted_time: Post  by Syeera » Mon Mar 26, 2007 3:54 pm

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Syeera, I commend your efforts to remain unencumbered by medicinal interventions by not taking medicines back to back.  I also feel for your having to battle ongoing headache issues for so long.  I would suggest you explore some non medicinal interventions for this current headache.  If this pain does not fit the profile you are used to with your ongoing migraines, and the traditional pain relievers are not touching it, it may be worthwhile exploring other options. I believe you may be correct in feeling this may be a tension headache, and if so, the more you are concerned about it the longer it will linger and plague you.  Have you explored massage therapy?  There are excellent LMT's (licensed massage therapists) who have been specially trained to address tension pain, you may wish to contact a local school to find one, or even ask your primary physician if he/she knows one they would refer you to.  You may also wish to seek evaluation by a DO (Dr. of Osteopathy) or a chiropractic physician, who may be able to assist you with this current problem, due to their holistic approach to healthcare.

title: headache/nausea, but NOT a migraine???
content: My boyfriend had a weird headache experience today...he awoke feeling all right, but within an hour he had excruciating pain behind his right eye, and was vomiting.  The nausea subsided after a few hours, but the pain continued all day.  Because I have chronic, classic migraines, I was interested to discover that he seemed to have no sensitivity to light or noise, like I always do,  and the pain was not pulsative, but steady.  Migraines always throb, because they are vein-related, right?  I did some research about cluster headaches, and it wasn't like one of those, either, since there was no tearing of the eye, and clusters don't seem to come with nausea.  Any insight would be greatly appreciated.
posted_time: Post  by windowsmeg » Fri Mar 23, 2007 12:08 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: There are a few possibilities.  Most likely, your boyfriend actually did have a variant of a migraine.  Commonly migraines are as you describe with the pounding head pain, sensitivity to light/noise, etc.  However, they can occur without these things.    He may also have an inner ear infection.  In this case, dizziness is also often occuring.  It is also possible that a nerve along that area (possibly from the sinuses) became inflamed causing the pain.  I think this is less likely given the progression of his symptoms.  When one has a sudden headache with vomiting, increased intracranial pressure must be considered.  A CT scan may be needed.  If there is any concern that this is not a typical headache (i.e. the pain is getting worse, the vomiting continues, any new symptoms develop) I would recommend that he be seen right away.  If your boyfriends headache does not get better or if anything else concerning develops I would strongly recommend that he be seen by a doctor.  Along with being able to do a thorough neurological exam and make a proper diagnosis, his doctor can likely give him some medication to help stop the headache.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I have a few possible ideas for you.  You mention you sit at the computer for long periods of time.  This alone can cause headaches and neck pain.  Be sure to take frequent breaks.  Do some neck stretches while working.  Try to sit with good posture.  Make sure your chair is adjusted properly.  You may be able to elevate your monitor some so that it is at eye level and you don't have to look down.  Another possibility is a migraine headache.  It would be a little unusual for a migraine to last for a month, however.  With a headache and neck pain, one must consider meningitis.  This, too, is pretty unlikely given that it has been going on for a month.  Meningitis typically will make you very sick or gets better after several days (neither of which, it seems, apply in your case).  I would be most suspicious of your symptoms being caused by chronic muscle tightness in your neck from your computer.    If your headaches do not improve I recommend you see your doctor for further evaluation.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by Mandy23 » Mon Feb 05, 2007 9:11 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Cluster headaches are headaches that occur in "clusters" by happening at around the same time of day and in the same area of the head (often behind the eye) for several days in a row.  It does not sound like you are having cluster headaches.  You may be experiencing inflammation of your galeal aponeurosis.  This is the band that connects the muscle of your forehead with the muscle of the back part of your head.  (This is the muscle system that allows you to raise your eyebrows.)  If this is the cause, treatment is with non-steroidal anti inflammatory meds (ibuprofen, etc.).  I would recommend that you see your doctor for an evaluation since there are a few other causes that should be checked for.  Best wishes.

content: It is possible that your headaches are related to diabetes or hypertension; however, there are some other much more likely causes.  You may have migraine headaches. author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: You may be experiencing migraine headaches, cluster headaches or even severe tension headaches.  Certainly a bulging disk can cause a headache but this is much less common than other symptoms related to this.  Often, with a bulging disk one will get shooting pains down the arms or other areas depending on which disk is the problem.  Keeping a headache diary can be helpful.  Record what time the headache started during the day, anything you were doing before hand, any food/drink you had in the recent time period, etc.  Occasionally this can reveal triggers to your headaches that can then be avoided.  This information can also be helpful to your doctor in diagnosing the problem.  If you do have migraines and are experincing these attacks somewhat frequently, you may be able to take a daily medication to help prefent the headaches from occuring.  I would recommend that you discuss your symptoms with your doctor.  Best wishes.

title: Headaches w/burning sensations
content: I am a 38 year old female with no headache history, but have low immune system and known for having chronic infections. On Feb 2, 2007 I had a horrible sharp pain and burning sensation shoot up the left side of my neck and head right behind my left ear. My head was extremely sensative to the touch as if someone had slammed me in the head with a hammer or something and bruised my head. This was extremely painful and brought tears to my eyes and I was going to go to the ER, but then the pain went away. It only lasted about 5 minutes and I was completely fine afterwards.   Three days later on the 5th, I developed these horrible headaches that I haven't been able to get rid of yet. Two days after that on the 7th, I developed a sore throat and sore neck, no coughing, no sinus drainage or anything else. When I developed those symptoms, I just automatically assumed the headaches were probably just part of that. However, my other  symptoms went away, but the headaches have continued. It has now been one month and 2 days.   The headache is a constant headache and it is not one sided, it bilateral, on the back of my head, the crown and forehead. It feels like something is squeezing my head really tight. There are times when I have burning sensations (not tingling, actual burning sensations) that accompany the sharp pains that I also get along with the constant pressure. I also have eye pain, but NO visual changes. Lights, sounds and smells do not bother me at all. No nausea, no vomiting, no other pain in neck or shoulders. These headaches were also waking me up out of a dead sleep in the middle of the night. I went to see my doctor finally on Feb 20th. All my bloodwork came back fine. He put me on Mobic and Butalbital-Apap-Caff which didn't help with the headaches at all.   I went back to see my doctor on March 1st because the burning sensations were starting to move into my face around my eyes and in my forehead. My blood pressure was up this time, it was 129/90 which is a little high, but he wasn't concerned about that because it was normal on the 20th when I was in his office. He said it wouldn't be uncommon for it to be elevated a little with me having such a bad headache. At this point, he took me off the other meds and now has started me out on 25mgs of Topomax and I had a MRI done. The MRI came back normal with the  exception of a small spot the size of the end of pin point in the white matter of my brain which the nurse said the radiologists didn't think it was anything to be alarmed about. I was told it could be from the onstart of possible migraines or possibly a dust particle on the film.    However, I have always understood that patients with migraines can't tolerate light or sound and none of those bother me, nor is my headache more one sided, nor do I have nausea or vomiting. Also, would a migraine last 24/7 for over a month?  Yesterday, I started having pain in my ears and the same burning sensations that I have had all over my head and in my eyes. My PCP said I may need to go see a neurologist at some point if the headaches continue, but now I am having the ear pain. So, does this sound more like something I would need to see a neurologist about or an ENT specialist?  I would also like to mention that I had abdominal surgery for a recurrent inguinal hernia back on July 24, 2006. I had a lot of post op swelling that caused the swelling to go over into my left thigh and put pressure on my sciatic nerve. I had to have a CT aspiration done in August to remove all of the fluid, but due the pressure that was put on the nerve in my leg. It irritated the nerve in my left leg leaving it numb from my inner thigh down to my knee with intermittent burning sensations. I'm still having problems with this, but surgeon assures me this will get better in time. Is it possible that this could all somehow be connected with the nerves?
