author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear jsabella, It would be better if you can give us more details about the pattern of headache he has, is it unilateral or starts as being in one side probably the same left side where there is numbness. Did he notice that this headache increase after stress, physical effort, some types of food etc. Is their any family history of migraine or another neurological disorders, diabetes mellitus? Did he check for Diabetes mellitus? Anyways, these symptoms can be part of migraine headache. Migraine is more than just a headache there is two types of migraine, classic one the headache is preceded by an aura of 15-60 minutes which normally occur before the headache begins; most commonly visual disturbances including blind spots, flashing lights; confusion, inability to concentrate, problems with articulation or co-ordination, or tingling, pins and needles or numbness on the affected side. The other form is common migraine that lacks this aura. Patients suffering from migraine  may complaint of some of these symptoms ( intense throbbing headache, often on one side of the head only,  nausea and/or vomiting and/or diarrhoea , increased sensitivity to light , increased sensitivity to sounds , and or increased sensitivity to smells ).  They may also experience stiffness of the neck and shoulders, tingling or stiffness in the limbs, an inability to concentrate, difficulty in speaking, or in rare cases paralysis or loss of consciousness. Although headache is the most obvious event during a migraine some patients start to feel "strange" a day or so before the attack begins. These strange feelings, known as the prodrome, are the first signs of the attack and can include cravings for certain foods, excitability, hyperactivity, tiredness, yawning or a change of mood. The causes and mechanisms of migraine are still under research however it is believed to be due to release of neurotransmitter called serotonin in the body. Many factors can trigger attacks in susceptible people: stress or sometimes the relief of stres, overtiredness (physical or mental), Extreme emotions (e.g. anger, grief), toothache or pain in the eyes, sinuses or neck, anxiety/Depression, sexual arousal. Regarding the frothy yellow saliva, it might be part of the condition with increases vagal tone during the attack or he might have another dental or mouth infection. Now what he should do, migraine is a complex and individual condition and it is important to persevere until we find the right treatment or combination of treatments and/or diet/lifestyle changes, which work, for each one. Your friend should visit a neurologist for full clinical assesment including full history, examination and investigations. This is the only way to find out the right diagnosis and to prescribe him the proper treatment since his complaints are not typical. Hope to hear from you soon.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear jsa,  Saliva is produced by both the major and minor salivary glands. There are three pairs of major salivary glands: the parotid, submandibular, and sublingual glands. These glands produce approximately 1.5 liters of saliva daily: 70% is from the submandibular glands, 25% is from the parotid glands, and 5% is from the sublingual glands. The secretory innervation of the salivary glands is primarily under the control of the parasympathetic nervous system.   True hypersecretion is seen in response to local irritation e.g. stomatitis (inflammatory disease of the oral mucus membranes), gingivitis (inflammation of the gums), dental disease, and in side effects to tranquilizers and anticonvulsants. Indirect causes, such as nasal obstruction, poor positioning lead to sialorrhea because of chronic mouth breathing or open mouth posture. Also some metabolic disorders and chemical or insect stings.  I could not understand well the silky sensation he gets. However, a metal taste some patients experience means an acidic saliva which is common with mostly kidney and gall stones, and tooth decay. A lso all degenerative diseases , including cancer, heart disease, arthritis, osteoporosis are associated with excess acidity in the body.  The pattern of fluctuation you have described goes more with local cause like dental problems or any sort of mouth infection that became chronic.  Thorough dental and medical evaluations including complete history and investigations are important to determine the causes of hypersalivation. Treatment includes control of the cause and prescribtion of specificdrugs that control secretion of the salivary glands.  With my best regards.

author: Dr. K. Eisele  Psychiatrist Posts: 328 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 10:32 pm Location: US
title: weird feeling in head
content: Jessica718:  Good evening, dear.  I'm sorry you're not well.  Have you told your parents about this?  If not, is there a particular reason?  To sort this out, let's first think about the infected ear lobe.  Just under the ear are some lymph nodes, called the anterior cervical chain.  If you have any "bumps" along that area of your neck, then you are on your way to a serious infection that requires a physical examination by a physician.  You also mentioned hurting all over and being tired all the time.  An infection of the ear lobe can result in systemic (body-wide) infection that can be very serious.  Since you mentioned dizziness, I have to wonder if that's what is going on.  There is another condition that could explain your symptoms.  You did think you might have depression.  Your symptoms do suggest anxiety, which goes hand-in-hand with depression.  Some patients have difficulty distinguishing between feelings of depression and anxiety.  Symptoms of depression include:  1.  depressed mood 2.  loss of interest in activities of daily living and previously enjoyable activities 3.  marked change in appetite 4.  marked change in sleep pattern 5.  feelings of guilt that are in excess for the situation 6.  distractibility 7.  low energy 8.  feelings of hopelessness/worthlessness 9  recurrent morbid thoughts (feelings of wanting to be dead) or suicidal thoughts (feeling like actually killing yourself)  If you have any thoughts of killing yourself or recurrent morbid thoughts, you must tell your parents immediately, or simply call 911 or go to the emergency room immediately.  Otherwise, proceed as follows.  You should definitely be seen by your doctor to take care of the infected earlobe, and while you're there, make sure you mention any and all symptoms of depression and anxiety that you have.  Get well, and come back to let us know how you're doing.

author: emortimer  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Jan 02, 2007 3:25 pm Location: Columbia, SC
title: Persistent headache for 2+ months
content: My partner is a 35 yr old female, previous migranes for a short period of her life but hasn't had them in several years.  Doesn't like meds, no smoking, no drinking, etc.  No fam history of migraines or headaches. Paternal and maternal cancers. Previous history of serious anorexia (for several years as adolescent...)  Currently:  Has had a headache every day since the end of Oct.  It occurred on Oct 27th (no reason, no trauma).  She awoke to a terrible headache with severe nausea and general unwell feeling.  Ibuprofen didn't help.  She has awoken to the headache every day since then, except one morning but headache came later that day.  It is worse in the morning, pounding, eases off through the day (sometimes goes away completely for periods of time), comes back at night and various times through day.  Pounds in her temples, stretches across front of her head.  Not tight, more pounding when at its worst.  As it dies away, it becomes a dull ache.  She has nausea, decreased appetite when the headache is on. Tingling in face (both sides, across top of head). Pain meds don't help. She tried some off and on but they didn't seem to help so she doesn't bother.  Has had what she thinks of as migraines years ago but says this is completely unlike any previous headache and is unrelentless.  Her spirit is broken, she cannot handle it anymore.    Went to a neurologist today.  NO bedside manner.  Completely condescending, had her in a box before she opened her mouth.  Read her description on previsit paperwork and had her pegged as rebound headaches.  Told him she doesn't take many meds, but he insists that must be it.    Went to ER this weekend b/c she had blurred vision with one of the headaches.  Blurred vision lasted all day, and she had swelling on her eyelids (which has seemed to have mostly gone away now).  She had a D&C last week (abnormal bleeding for 6 months) and we thought blurred vision was perhaps from Anesthesia as it occured the next day?  Went to ER, they did CT which showed nothing.  Gave her twice her body weight's worth of Toradol.  30mg IV, she's 110lbs with clothes on.  Bad reaction... scared her.  Gave it before CT.  I've read that Toradol before CT can skew results?  Now contsant burning in stomach, aggravated by foods since ER visit.  Headache was relieved to dull ache with Toradol but was back with vengeance by the time we got home from ER.  She had been on 800mg Ibuprofen 3x day for last few days after D&C and that didn't even touch the headache.  Anyway, this Neurologist didn't even ask her to describe her headache or what may be different about it than normal, what concerns her, etc.  Gave her rx for ??  something for migraine w/rebound headaches and sent her away.    Is it possible that that's all it is?  She's frightened and so am I.  Would have felt much more comfortable if he had done MRI or MRA.  What if???   Gulp.  Any advice?  -Emma

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,   It would be more helpful if you can inform us more about the characters of this swelling like size, associated scalp infection, history of recent trauma etc.   This swelling could be : - Folliculitis, it is an infection of the hair follicles. Forming small, white-headed Bumps in hair follicles (roots).  Lesions may be Itching. Superficial folliculitis resolves spontaneously in a few days, while deep or recurring folliculitis should be medically treated.   - Seborrheic dermatitis, which occurs where the skin is oily or greasy like the scalp. Secondary bacterial infections may occur forming swellings that need antibiotic local treatment.  - An enlarged lymph node as reactionary to infection in the area drained by them like scalp infections or lesions.  Most of the lesions are soft to firm , may be painful and tender.  - A traumatic lesion which may pass unnoticed. The swelling is felt as hard but pain and tenderness may be present.  Direct clinical examination is essential. Keep us updated. Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Thu Jan 25, 2007 6:37 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  There are many causes of chronic headache. It could be a manifestation of an elevated blood pressure, neck problems, eye problems, ear problems or sinus problems.  Sinus headache is usually worse in the morning and on bending over. It may feels like a painful fullness. The area over the sinus is usually tender. If present it may show on the CT scan.  There are two types of migraine classic and common types. Common migraine has all the characteristics of a migraine but lacks the aura. It is important to differentiate common migraine from another form of headache called common tension headache.  Tension headache is diffuse, steady with band-like distribution and occurs mainly in the evening.  I hope this may have helped.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Mon Jan 15, 2007 8:27 am

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  This is very similar to migraine headache although not typical. Focal neurological symptoms may occur with the headache and persist temporarily in case of a migraine variant. One of these variants is ophthalmoplegic migraine in which a third nerve palsy, with ptosis may occur. Although rare , it is reported in some adults.  The attack usually lasts from days to months and resolves spontaneously.  A thorough neurological examination should be done to exclude conditions involving the parasellar, orbital, and posterior fossa which also present with headache and ophthalmoplegia..  Sinusitis give similar headache but the pain is often exacerbated by leaning forward or head movement, the involved sinus are the sites where the headache is felt and tenderness on palpation of the involved sinus is present.  Direct clinical examination is essential for diagnosis. If his condition is not improving, I advise you to follow up with his Doctor and to go for further investigations to exclude other causes.  Hope this information is useful. Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Fri Dec 29, 2006 5:48 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,   The swelling you have described that is felt on the left upper side of the neck is probably enlarged Lymph nodes as it occurs in a Lymph node region, however this must be confirmed by your physician.   Abnormal Lymph node enlargement commonly results from infection / immune response, cancer.   Following infection Lymph nodes become enlarged, painful and tender.   A history of scalp infected lesions, or Ear infection may be present, as this lymph node could be a reactionary to infection in the area drained by this lymph node group.   After treatment of infection with adequate course of antibiotics, they regress in size but never to normal size.   Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are significant and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.   Direct clinical examination is essential to exclude other causes like abscess, bone lesion, etc.  Keep us updated.  Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Fri Dec 29, 2006 3:56 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Its a route of administration of a drug. Drugs can broadly be given (adminstered) topically (locally) when the drug substance is applied directly where its action is desired (eg, skin creams applied on the skin is topical adminstration of the cream).  When the desired effect is systemic (non-local) the substance can be given either via the digestive tract (tablets or capsules) or parenterally (eg, intramuscular injections or intravenous injections).  So for example systemic adminstration of steroids would be steroids that are given systemically (tablets, injections) and NOT topically (not steroid creams).  Sorry if I tried too hard to oversimplify things.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: There are many treatments for tension headaches.  I would recommend talking to your doctor about them.  One thing to consider, though, is that headaches, fatigue, and the other symptoms you describe can all be signs of the depression coming back.    If you are feeling depressed again, or think this may be causing your symptoms you should talk with your doctor.  Zoloft is one of many antidepressants.  Several have generic forms that may be cheaper.  Also, occasionally drug companies have programs that can help supply medications when people can't afford them.    Another avenue to think about is counseling.  Often, this can be very effective in conjunction with the antidepressants to help in ultimately trying to alleviate the need for the medicine.  Generally there are clinics that will provide free counseling if needed.  I hope you feel better soon.  Headaches and depression can be very difficult to deal with.  Best wishes.  Incidentally, some antidepressants can help you stop smoking as well, if you're interested.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  it is difficult to tell without direct clinical examination what this swelling could be and whether it is related to the migraine history or not (although remote possibility).  This swelling could be: - An enlarged Lymph node as it occurs in a Lymph node region, however this must be confirmed by direct examination.  Abnormal Lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).   Sometimes, following infection Lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.   Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter. Having tenderness, soreness around and other signs of inflammation make an infectious cause is more likely to be considered. Usually a course of antibiotic is tried to  improve the symptoms and to allow further management.   - An abscess: Abscess is the body responds to bacteria or to a foreign body as white blood cells migrate to the affected area, attack and destroy them forming pus. An abscess may form on top of any other swelling or mass.   Swelling in this part of the neck may alone cause severe headache,  increase the severity of already existing migraine.  The personal and medical history as well as the clinical examination gives a good idea about the possible nature of this node. Further investigations include, US guided FNAC or biopsy.  Keep us updated. Best regards.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Approximately 60% of headache onset occurs in those older than 20 years.  There are many causes of headache. It could be a manifestation of an elevated blood pressure, neck problems, eye problems, ear problems or sinus problems.  Migraine is defined as severe, episodic, unilateral, throbbing headache. There are two main types of migraine, classic and common.   In the classic one the headache is preceded by aura of 15-60 minutes duration which normally occurs before the headache begins. The aura are commonly visual disturbances including blind spots, flashing lights, confusion, inability to concentrate, problems with articulation or co-ordination, or tingling, pins and needles or numbness on the affected side.   The other form is common migraine which has all the characteristics of a migraine but lacks the aura. It is important to differentiate common migraine from common tension headache.   In tension type headache both muscular and psychogenic factors are believed to be associated with tension-type headache.  As mentioned earlier it is also very likely to be a sinus problem.  I would suggest that since you are having headaches on a daily basis that its imporant that you pay a visit to your doctor.  Best regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  I hope you are feeling better.  There are many causes of headache. It could be a manifestation of an elevated blood pressure, neck problems, eye problems, ear problems or sinus problems.  I wouldn't put cavernous sinus thrombosis at the top of the list. You do not seem to have any cranial nerve affection, you didn't mention fever and there is a good chance that the CT scan would have picked it up.  However, one disease known as temporal arteritis may be worth consideration. Then again I wouldn't put it at the top of the list either but it may be worth while to discuss this with your doctor.  Temporal (giant cell) arteritis is an inflammatory disorder of arteries that frequently involves the extracranial carotid circulation. Temporal arteritis occurs mainly in white women in their late life. Autoimmune processes presumably provide the cause.  New, severe, sustained, steady or throbbing headache most often located in the temporal region of the scalp and accompanied by a tender, nodular, or incompressible artery in the area. Head pain also may affect the masseter or sterno­cleidomastoid muscles, occasionally as the chief symptom.  Associated symptoms may include malaise, fatigue, weight loss, low-grade fever, and proximal myalgia affecting the pectoral or pelvic girdle areas (polymyalgia rheumatica). The erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) usually rises to 60 mm/hr or more.   A firm diagnosis requires a biopsy. Pathological examination of the offending temporal artery usually shows an inflammatory response, often with partial or complete occlusion of the lumen.   Temporal arteritis represents a medical emergency, since delaying proper treatment increases the risk of retinal artery occlusion, thereby producing partial or com­plete functional loss of vision.  High dose corticosteroids is given in the presence of a probable clinical diagnosis. Remarkable resolution within 24hrs is the rule.  Follow up twice monthly for symptoms and ESR to detect relapse.  Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Wed Nov 22, 2006 6:30 am

These  jolt me awake again and the cycle can continue for  hours. I have seen my  Doctor a number of times,  searched the  internet at length, but have not found anyone else with this condition.   In late 2004 I saw a consultant and had an MRI scan that was normal. He put me on  Indomethacin, 25mg of  which usually works fine and other than nightly very unpleasant dreams  was dealing with the problem. I went along by  invitation to the London  Headache Group, who were  baffled.   I have over the last 18 months had maybe 3 or 4  periods of a few days  when the drugs haven't worked, and found that  increasing the dose  usually fixed it. However, I have now had 2 weeks  where the drugs are  not working. I have increased the dose from 25mg  through 50g to 75mg to  100mg without guarantee of success. Last night for  example, I took 100mg  at 10.15pm, went to bed at 11.15pm, and the pains started  as I fell asleep. I got about 4 hours sleep.   I am only getting 3, 4 or 5 hours sleep a night, the  rest being  interrupted by these short pains, which are like  someone flicking the  inside of my right temple. I usually have, and need  7 or 8 hours sleep a  night. I am very worried and very tired.       Any help really appreciated.

content: I have to say that I think this forum is a waste of time; there are loads of people asking for help and no help forthcoming.  Anyway, in case it helps anyone, my consultant recommended a lumbar puncture, which I had on Tuesday. They are apparently successful in about 30% of cases of unexplained headaches, so we gave it a go. It wasn't pleasant, although not as bad as I feared.   The good news is that after 27 months on drugs (indomethacin or epilim) to greater or lesser effect, my unexplained stabbing pains at the point of falling asleep have gone.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  - In most of the cases with neck, (upper back) pain, spasm of the back muscles, is the primary cause. This usually results fromMuscle fatigue, Heavy exercise and wrong posture.  Muscle spasm alone can cause the pain which can be an unidentified cause.  In these cases, self care and avoiding the precipitating cause will lead to a gradual but clear improvement in the pain. Home treatment includes the use of analgesics, cold or hot therapy. Rest for maximum two days is also beneficial.   If these measures fail to relief the pain or to improve symptoms in 48 hours, you should visit your doctor for better evaluation and for exclusion of other causes (like cervical disc prolapse) that need specific therapy.

author: Synergie  Guest Posts: 16 Joined: Sun Jun 12, 2005 9:48 pm Location: Canada
title: Occipital Neuralgia or Migrane?
content: Hi I was wondering if anyone could shed some light on this...  About a year ago, I had a horrible headache that stemmed from the base of my skull, and radiated pretty much to my entire head.  I was told it was occipital neuralgia, and that trigger point injections of local anesthetic would work to break the cycle of pain.  That time it did.   Jump to about a week ago, I had the same sort of horrible headache crop up.  It started out tolerable but landed me in the emergency room by Friday night.  I could barely think through the pain, my eyes were sensitive from light, and sounds hurt my ears. I couldnt eat because my stomach was so upset.  I had tears streaming down my face and my hands were balled into fists when my Mother took me to the ER.    I told them about the bout with occipital neuralgia about a year ago, and that the pain was in the same area... stemming from the base of my skull on both sides, and radiating up around my entire head.  The doctor wanted to be thorough though and did a lumbar puncture to be sure (he said he was looking for blood etc)  Then he put me on an IV with 'Procglorperazine' and benadryl. And then a second IV bag with Dexamethasone (steroid?) He said he was looking at this as a 'vascular' headache.  My questions are this:  I read that prochlorperazine is an antipsychotic? Would this have worked on occipital neuralgia? I did feel the medication 'kick in' and it seemed to lessen the headache.  Could this have been something other than occipital neuralgia then... more specifically could I have had a migrane? I have not really had migranes before though....  Second question is... the original headache was dampened down quite a bit by the medication they gave me, but not totally gone.  And now a few days after the ER visit, I have a different headache.  If I stand up or cough or move around more, its worse.   read that lumbar punctures can cause a headache... so I am wondering if this could be what I am experiencing now.  I am hoping its not the original headache making a come back.  Thanks in advance...

title: recent onset of nightime only, consistently timed headaches
content: Hi..   I am a 41 YO white Female.The onle surgery I have had was a C-section is 99.No other health issues,other than pretty severe seasonal alergies,loud snoring and about 30 lbs overweight.  No current medications.  Problem. About a year ago,I began having very strange night time only headaches.The normally occur between 3:00 - 4:30 Am..Never later...I am usually in bed between 10:30 -midnight. The headaches normally awaken me..with a vise like grip around the back of my head.I have found if I awake early enough,before the pain gets too severe,and walk around and do deep breathing..It will go away.If I remain lying down,the pain remains,increases to unbearable.Sometimes if I lay down after they go away I am OK.Other times they reoccur stronger. When they are the strongest,again if I get up and walk around,it will lesson.Taking baths alternating very hot and very cold water,usually eliminates them all together.They usually last about 2 hours when they are at their worst.I have never had one last past 7 AM and have never had one during the daytime hour.The timing of them seems to occur about a week before menstruation and half-way between,which leads me to think it may be pre-menopausal.But have found nothing to support this. Have also suspected mild sleep epnea,due to loud snoring,but no other symptoms... I have never gotten one of these headaches during daytime napping..  Mother,now deceased from complications to Diabetes,congestive heart failure and sarcoidosis..Had sever alergy headaches. I have associated a possible link with tomatoe based products,but have had them without consuption as well...  Have also suspected additives such as MSG....But again,prevailing factors are same time of the night,same time of the month...Any input would be greatly appreciated.

content: Hi cathou, The headaches occurring at the same time each month and at the same time each night would possibly indicate that your complaint is hormone related. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am

content: Hi kirk99, Exertional headaches during sexual activity are often benign in nature. However, since this can not be concluded without a physical evaluation by your physician, I would suggest this be completed to rule out any underlying cause. If you are somewhat embarrassed, especially with disclosing this information to your wife, then just tell her that you have been having headaches lately and are going into have an evaluation. Masturbation as long as you feel comfortable doing this, is by no means an unheard of practice. When you go in for an evaluation, explain to the physician, that the headaches occur primarily with sexual activity, as masturbation is a sexual activity. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

title: Heightened Blood Pressure Induced Headache
content: Hello,  I am a 21 year old male, 6'0", 195 lbs with an athletic build.  I attend a large university and go to the gym a few times a week.  Primarily my workout consists of jumping rope, push ups, sit ups, leg ups, and medicine ball work; easy stuff.  A few weeks ago something went wrong.  When I do my pushups I alternate looking left and right on the way down.  This makes me feel like I'm getting an equal workout for both arms.  On the way down I looked right and then something seemed to release on the back of my neck/head and a terrible headache ensued.  It was localized to strictly the back of my head and is a throbbing headache.  I continued my workout regardless of the pain.  Since then I have noticed that the same headache, although reduced in severity, occasionally when my blood pressure/heart rate goes up.  The frequency and severity is going down.  I can go to the gym and have no problems.  I do still get them however for certain.  What is happening or what had happened?  Thanks.  Matt
posted_time: Post  by matt20017 » Tue Feb 21, 2006 9:21 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi matt20017, Exertional headaches sometimes occur, ie, in people that are more susceptible to episodes of migraines. However, they may also be caused by underlying abnormalities. Any sudden, severe headache, especially brought about by exertion, warrants a diagnostic work-up. I would strongly suggest that you have an evaluation by your physcian to identify if an underlying causative factor is present. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Headache just about everyday...
content: Dear Andrea,  With your husband's history it is not surprising that your husband has headaches.  All the surgeries, the sinus problems, the neck problems and the tmj all lead to headaches.  Your husband has to make sure his blood pressure is not high and that his vision is good because they might cause headaches.  If the headaches continue to be a real problem to your husband, he has to be evaluated by a doctor and if needed (if considered by his doctor), your husband might need to be evaluated by a neurologist specialized in headaches.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and I hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

Everyday since roughly 5 years ago (Im unclear as to when this started exactly, it seemed to just come on me slowly, seemingly when i moved into the back room in my parents house) i have been experiencing constant pressure in top/front of my head. it is nonstop, and it is often accompanied with nausea and a feeling of iminent sickness.   Other symptoms that have accumulated are a constant ringing in the ears (subtle, can only hear it and is bothersome when it is quiet or relative silence) and pain when using q-tips. I also have dark spots in my eyes, and what i call heat/mirage vision which is like tiny little black spots and a 'heatwave' like sight (only noticeable when looking at white objects or the sky for example) as well as seeing transparent 'shapes' usually like a string with a loop in it or something, hard to explain. I have also had a chronic cough, which depending on the time of year will produce phlegm usually green or yellow with brown spots in it and shortness of breath and fatigue. And I don't smoke, however I do smoke when I occasionally drink on the weekends.  I have seen an ENT, received 2 left frontal sinus surgeries because of a cyst/infection. As of now my sinuses are clear, so I went to the Houston Headache Clinic and stayed in the hospital for 5 days on intervenous IV medication as well as oral. My symptoms were never relieved, and barely alleviated. I now take Depakotee 500mg and Cafergot for the 'headaches' which don't really help, pulmicort and albuterol for the cough and recently taken Azithromycin and Ketek for sore throat/coughing/etc.   I have also done several CT scans, a CAT scan and an MRI, all of which were fine, and these were taken about a year ago. Ive also seen a neurologist and a psychiatrist, was prescribed geodon for paranoia type symptoms but other than that, nothing. Ive seen all these people and never have my symptoms gone away. All i know is that they never go away, and for some reason the nausea/pressure and headache discomfort are much worse after I take a hot shower or steam, or when I excercise, and i feel really 'out of it' like im kinda not there, a terrible feeling.  Needless to say I feel helpless about this, and i have many symptoms other than this i wasnt sure where to put this thread. Nothing so far has helped so I am asking a doctor on this board to please look into this, check it out. My name is Eric Giebel and live in Midland, Texas. Im beginning to wonder if it isnt something in my enviromnent (my home) is keeping my sick, as I am quite allergic to black mold. Is that possible ? Sorry for the length but I feel like everything must be explained. thanks in advance

author: Hayley  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Mon Jan 16, 2006 10:45 pm Location: California
title: Unitlateral headache for 8 days now!  Been to doctor twice!
content: I need my mind put at ease.  I have had what is being called a migraine/tension headache (depending on which doctor you talk to) for the past going on 8 days.  It is on the left side of my headand sharp at times, sometimes feeling like it is pulling if I move my head down or a certain way, my temple is very tender, and it extends up behind my ear and down towards the back of my left side of my head.  It is there when I wake up in the morning and has woke me up before if I roll over on that side of my head.  I have had no nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light or sound, sinus pain, loss of appetite, change in vision, or dizziness.  I have not had any recent injuries.  It is there all day in varying degrees, getting jabbing and throbbing at times, sometimes with movement, sometimes not.  I have taken Tylenol, Darvocet N-100, 800 mg of Ibuprofen, Flexeril, and today I actually got a Toradol shot at the doctors.  The only thing that worked was the Toradol shot, but it did come back after about10 hours (I actually thought it would be gone after that long, I couldnt believe it came back AGAIN!).  Today in the waiting room at the doctor, I had a brief ringing in both of my ears that also felt like someone put their hands over my ears and everything sounded very dull.  The only med I am on on a daily basis is atenolol 25 mg a day.  I have no prior history of migraines and I am a 38 year old female.  The first doctor I saw (5 days into the headache) told me it was a tension headache and totally normal for it to last this long, even longer.  She gave me some Midrin (which I havent taken yet due to the other medications I had tried).  She also told me it should be gone by the end of the weekend.  Well, today (Monday) I was back in in tears because of the pain.  I wake up in pain every morning.  This doctor told me it was a migraine even though I had no other migraine symptoms and no migraine history.  She gave me the Toradol shot and told me to take the Midrin if it came back.  She also drew some blood and will call me tomorrow if anything showed up as abnormal.  She said very rare causes could also be stroke or arteritis, which she says I am too young for and have showed no other symptoms for.  I Googled a lot of information and have never heard of a headache lasting so long. I am getting worried that it may be someting more serious.  Now that the pain has just come back after the Toradol shot, I am also feeling a bit of tingling in that area of my head where the headache is and some very slight face tingilng on that side.  What is happening?  Will this EVER go away?  I just need some reassurance that this will end.  Thank you so much.  Please be kind  enough to reply if you have any answers.  I cant find anyone who has had the exact symptoms as I have on the message boards as of yet.  Thank you in advance, ~A

author: drgreghaitz  Guest Posts: 14 Joined: Mon Mar 28, 2005 12:26 pm Location: 514 - 28 1/4 Road Suite 1, Grand Junction, Colorado 81501
title: Headache
content: Hayley,  Sorry to hear about the scarry headaches.  The nerves that go to the face originate from the brain and cervical spine (neck).  As a doctor of chiropractic, I see this all the time in my practice.  It usually is a problem with the one or two of the upper three vertebra in the neck as well as some suboccipital muscle tightness.  The numbness could be a mononeuropathy which means that there is some compression on a nerve causing numbness.  Consisder seeing a doctor of chiropractic.  This stuff is our specialty.  to find one in your area go to http://www.amerchiro.org and click on "find a doctor of chiropractic" in the top of the page.  Good luck!
posted_time: Post  by drgreghaitz » Thu Jan 26, 2006 5:40 pm

author: Hayley  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Mon Jan 16, 2006 10:45 pm Location: California
title: I have a diagnosis
content: Well, they are telling me I have GREATER OCCIPITAL NEURALGIA.  My doctor consulted a neurologist, told him my symptoms, and it took him all of 5 seconds to say that is what it is.  She was going to send me to the CAT scanner and after she talked to him, he told her to hold off, because he diagnosed me with the neuralgia.  They put me on 800 mg ibuprofen 3 times a day, Flexeril, and nortryptiline for 3 weeks.  The ibuprofen is for the inflammation because apparently the nerve exits out the back of your neck and goes over your skull, and if the muscles are tight they can compress the nerve, irritating it.  The Flexeril is a muscle relaxant, and the nortryptiline is actually a tricyclic antidepressant that is used in a low dose for nerve pain.  Apparently, this condition is pretty chronic, so Im expecting it to not completely go away unless I am able to get some kind of physical therapy or something.  They said if the pain is still there in 3 weeks, they will give me a nerve block injection in the area of my head where the nerve is.  This is only temporary though.  I still do have pain, although not as bad.  It is always there and worse when I first wake up in the morning.  It usually dies down during the day, and then can come back either in the side back of my head or in my temple area on that side at different times.  I also tried buying a pillow with more support to see if that helps support where the nerve is during the night.  Anyone with any input or knowledge or experience with this, please feel free to post.  Of course, part of me is still scared they misdiagnosed me, but 3 weeks later, and I am still walking and talking,so who knows!  Ciao!

title: constant headache,numbing in face,dizziness
content: I am a 26 year old female.  On Dec. 3, I woke up feeling like the room was spinning in circles and this lasted for about a week.  My doctor thought it was either vertigo or labrinthitis.  The next week, I began having headaches which have escalated to being constant.  The pain is all across the back of my head and seems to "surge" in nature.  My vision and hearing are fine, but I would describe my vision as "just not quite right."  I have been unable to concentrate and everything just seems a little off.  Three days ago, after having a horrible headache for 48 hours straight, the right side of my face went numb and I got very disoriented.  My hands were shaking as well.  I went to the hospital where they did an MRI and bloodwork - all normal.  I am now waiting about a month to get into a neurologist for further testing.  I was initally prescribed STA-D (for ear drainage) and antivert for dizziness.  My ears never hurt, but have been popping- could this be due to the STA-D, though? I have also been prescribed Fioricet for pain and advised to take Exederin Migraine (which does not really help).  I have been unable to work as looking at a computer screen only makes things worse.  Light and noise aggrevate symptoms.  I want to just stay in a quiet,dark room - it is the only thing that lessens the symptoms.  My eyes feel a bit heavy and I have slight pain behind the eyes; I assume this is from forcing myself to focus and concentrate.  Sharp head movements, bending over, and other fast movements all cause slight dizziness/disorientation (but the room spinning stopped about 2 weeks ago).  No one seems to have any idea what this could be and I don't know if I'm taking the proper meds for the symptoms in the meantime.   I don't take any regular medications.  I have been on Depo-Provera birth control for about 9 years.  No history of headaches or major medical problems.  I have been an athlete all my life and eat very healthy.  No drug use and non-smoker.  Any ideas or recommendations would be appreciated.

author: Antsoppki  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Fri Jan 13, 2006 4:36 pm Location: Yonkers
title: I Understand
content: I am losing my mind. I had an episode in October of 05, it started with a bad migraine followed by vertigo, followed by left sided facial/neck/shoulder numbness and slurred speech. Saw my PCP that day, and got a CT scan which was "normal". Was given T#3 for pain. Saw a neurologist 2 weeks later and had MRI and EEG done. MRI was "normal" and EEG results were not explained to me, but it's was referred to as an "EE Wow". It is now January of 06 and after an emergency room visit for pain I could not tolerate, I was given Butalbital 50mg and told to see a neuro. The next day I saw yet another and I am now being sent for an MRA of the Circle of Willis and an MRI with IV GAD. (About time) Was given yet another script for Topamax. Was told of possible "mini stroke" or TIA with possible atherosclerosis in the carotid's (which my mother had). Blood was taken to rule out MS (again, MOM) and Lyme disease as well as a battery of others. Symptoms still persist, the migraines are more frequent at once a week lasting 2-3 days of hellish pain since my October incident. Have been on a braod spectrum of medication over the past and found little or no relief at times.   Don't give up, and keep pressure on your doctors.  Do research on everything, and ask for copies of all your scans and correspondence between doctors and hospitals.  Keep changing doctors if you don't get answers and push for more tests.  Don't just let them throw more pills at it.  Good luck!

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Headaches, dizziness, and more...
content: Dear Hartmann,   The sinusitis headache actually is one of the worst. It is not in the back of the head. It is usually located on the front and the pain sometimes is where the sinus is located, meaning on the forhead, or below the eyes (the cheeks), or behind the eyes as there is a sinus behind the eyes.  Somtimes, if you have severe sinusitis, tenderness (pain on touch) is one way to diagnose the presence of sinusitis. So, yes, it can hurt to touch.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

content: I have been experiencing very severe headaches 1-3  times per week in the last 2.5 months. Tylenol Allergy and Sinus helps with most of the headaches once they've started.   What is causing these headaches?!  They are excruciating.  Are they linked to my cold extremities? title: Headache caused by stress
content: I have been suffering from headaches for the last 5-6 years.  It is usually associated with fatigue and stress and occurs once or twice a month.  The pain usually spreads from the rear part of the skull and I often feel the presence of a fluid within.  Recently I consulted a neurologist who examined me and took a VEEG and blood test.   He found nothing wrong in the test results and told me that this is due to a chemical change in the brain and advised me to manage stress and tension.  To prevent this headache he prescribed the following medicines.    Divalproex Sodium Extended Release Tablets- 250 mg – 1-0-1 Flupentixol and melitracen)Tablets- (Deanxit) – 1-0-0 Flunarizine Hydrochloride Tablets  10 mg – 0-0-1 Fluoxetine Capsules 20 mg 0-1-0  He asked me to continue this for a month and to observe the frequency of the occurrence of headaches and then depending on that he said he will modify the dosage.  He said I will have to continue this for another 3 months and stopping this in between may have reverse effects.   I am taking these drugs and now I feel very much sleepy.  I want to know whether there are any adverse effects for these drugs and whether this course is appropriate.  Can this headache be prevented if I take these drugs or is it better to ignore it?
posted_time: Post  by mayavidhu » Sat Oct 01, 2005 12:05 pm

author: DeLWolcott  Guest Posts: 293 Joined: Fri Jun 24, 2005 5:47 pm Location: Texas
title: [no title]
content: Each of these medications taken alone can cause increased fatigue, so it is understandable to me that you are experiencing this while taking all of them.  Some notes -   1.  There is no proof or tests for chemical imbalances in the brain.   2.  Depakote/ Divalproex - Can cause/increase depression. 3.  Deanxit should not be taken while taking any other antidepressant, particularly an       MAOI.  4.  Flunarizine/Sibelium - Can cause/increase depression. 5.  Prozac/fluoxetine - is an antidepressant, but is NOT an MAOI.  Deanxit and Sibelium are not available here in the US, so someone in your area may have access to much more information about these medications than I.    Your symptoms do point to tension headaches, but the infrequency (in my opinion, pharmacologic, not MD) should not warrant this combination, nor amount of medications on a daily basis.  Stopping these medications could have reverse effects and the longer you remain on the Prozac in particular, the more intense the reverse/rebound effects could be.  If possible, sit down with your physician and both of you compare the adverse reactions and other sections of the prescribing information together.  This way you can ask your questions and he can give you full answers so you may understand, or even rethink his combination of medications.  Either way, your physician should give you the full explanation of your treatment.  I wish you the best!

author: angel2close  Guest Posts: 37 Joined: Fri Apr 08, 2005 4:53 pm Location: Arkansas
title: [no title]
content: Unfortunately there is no such thing as normal for a migriane. Each and every person who suffers from migraines has different 'auras', different tolerances for the pain, etc. Migraines in and of themselves are not what 'we' consider 'normal'.  I believe that you have the answer to your question though already. If your doctor is 'pressuring' you to see a Neurologist, than I think that is what you should do. If one test is normal than it is customary for doctors to conduct other testing and/ or refer you to a specialist to find an answer. I suggest that you follow your doctor's suggestion and see a Neurologist.

author: dlugose  Guest Posts: 38 Joined: Tue Feb 22, 2005 6:08 pm Gender: Male Location: Boulder, CO, USA
title: [no title]
content: Well, I am a nurse with a couple ideas, and I hope you get more answers.   Sometimes alcohol and caffeine have effects on whether you het a headache or not, and I have had a few headaches during sex.  If they don't persist they may not be something to worry about, but do these occur with alcohol?  Of course that is only one factor; at other times alcohol does not cause headaches. Alcohol is a vasodilator and caffeine (or nicotine) is a vasoconstrictor.  If you use both, by evening the caffeine has worn off and the alcohol; may be effective.   Of possible concern, see for example http://www.neuro.wustl.edu/headache/dis ... system.htm where it says "There are, nevertheless several symptoms, which should raise the suspicion that the headache may be secondary to a serious medical problem.  These include 1) the sudden onset of headache during vigorous physical activity, including sex, particularly if severe or associated with other symptoms, 2) alteration of consciousness, 3) stiff neck, 4) worsening of headache, 5) abnormal signs on neurological and/or general physical examination."

title: [no title]
content: Well there are lots of possibilities, and the danger is that whatever I say, even if correct, may reassure you when you really need a complete history and physical by a good doctor.  Perhaps the back injury and headache were coincidental.  Perhaps straining caused a little bleeding in some blood vessel that first day that was related to the headache.  Although some article ares reassuring that sexual headaches are not uncommon, (see http://headaches.about.com/cs/triggers/a/ha_orgasm.htm ), even if you don't have medical insurance, if the headaches are not going away I would find someone to diagnose, perhaps at a community clinic with free or sliding scale fees.  Dan

author: radiodoc100  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Fri Sep 30, 2005 12:21 pm Location: Jamaica
title: scalp tightnessand light headedness
content: Dear Dedo, These are typical anxiety symptoms and common around the menopause. If you think about it, hormone replacement is very hit and miss, and does not, of itself, address the psychological symptoms that are so common at the menopause. If you ever suffered from irritability or weepiness premenstrually you will have no problem accepting that tiems of hormonal change disrupt the psyche! Around  the menopause one's eostrogen and progesterone levels swing wildly, another reason why HRT has been shown not to help with the psyche symptoms. The fact that you have had valium to no effect should not be a reason for you to doubt a diagnosis of anxiety (or possibly depression which is often a fellow traveller of ansiety). Both anxiety and depresion are now usually treated with the SSRI group of drugs, which are very effective and have been shown to be the best way of treating anxiety and depression during  menopause.Of course, I would also hope that some therapy would be available. Therapy AND medication are always used together for anxiety and depression symptoms. The trouble with anxiety is that it makes one doubt the diagnosis and the treatment. That's hard to address on line, and you need to see a doctor in person. Either a GP with an interest in psychiatry or a psychiatrist. This does not mean you are crazy! How does one know that light headedness and scalp tightness are due to anxiety? Its a presentation that we see very very frequently. I'm often asked that question, I usually reply that that is like asking "how do you know that is an elephant?".  Ask for referral to a good psychiatrist, or discuss with your doctor whether you suffer from an anxiety state or depression. These states are easy to diagnose, and treat.Its the very anxiety, however, that makes it difficult for you to accept the diagnosis. Good luck! Anxiety symptoms are awful things to suffer from.

author: radiodoc100  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Fri Sep 30, 2005 12:21 pm Location: Jamaica
title: Pressure in the head, anxiety, grieving
content: Dear Billy-Ray, I wrote you a long reply which may have got lost in cyber space! Essentially I was saying that grieving, when unfinished, can cause anxiety. I would guess this might be what is happening to you. Could you find a bereavement group that you could go to in order to work through your gief over your father's death? Ask your GP re this perhaps, or your pastor.  Your symptoms do not sound physical, but I would hope that your doctor has tapped out your reflexes and tested your muscle power and done some tests on your cranial nerves (looking at the back of the eye was part of this testing). These tests would tell us if there were, or were not,what we call a space occupying lesion. in your brain, and would be adequate to rule out any significant growth.  If I were your GP I would ask you questions to ascertain if your were suffering from an anxiety state, or possibly depression secondary to a prolonged grief reaction. If you were I would probably try a trial of SSRI medications which treat anxiety and depression, and are not addictive. If this relieved the pressure in your head, great! It  would take at least 3 weeks before we knew if the tablets were working since  this  is how long these medications take to start to be effective. If they made no difference I would consider referral to a neurologist. Worry is a terible thing, and telling a patient not to worry is not helpful, as you know! Ask  the doctor to treat the worry, then see if the pressure feeling go. I think you will find that they do. Good luck!

title: [no title]
content: It seems that you are having panic attacks (Anxiety).  I was feeling the same as you 2 months ago at the begining of my headache problem. I couln't eat, sleep, concentrate, listen to music, breathing problems, swallowing and more. The headache  that you are experiencing could be from a lot of things. The first one that you have to deal with is ANXIETY. Try to relax as much as possible and really talk to yourself that you are not going to die and this problem that you have will be solve. If that doesn't work then go to another Dr. and ask for some Lorazepam medicine to treat your anxiety. Take it only when your ANXIETY level is high. I know this for a fact because I have used Lorapam at the begining of my problem and it really does work. But you really must see another Dr. if your problem escalate. So, take it easy and RELAX.

title: HEADACHE, NECK, UPPER BACK (SHOULDERS) PAIN
content: I'm new to this site, so please bare with me...About 2 months ago (Mid July 2005) I’ve had a bicycle accident and hit the electricity post with my head. Everyone thinks it's funny but that how it all started. At the time I refused to see a doctor or go to the hospital because I thought it was nothing and endured the pain with left black eye for 2 weeks. I'm very actively fit so I still continue to exercise everyday (running, biking, walking, boxing, yoga and more). Then my family and I got invited to go to Six Flags. And of course knowing myself, I had to have fun and experience some rides. We did Pandemonium which I thought was weak and Twister was fantastic but then after the ride I wasn’t feeling well and felt nauseated. So needless to say, we had to stop and went home. A week later …   August 9, 2005 – Sleep all day (Wasn’t feeling good) -	Boxing for 30 mins to warm up -	Run w/ Brother around seven/eight -	Drank Pilon Expresso shot  -	Energy booster up -	Weight lifted for 30 mins. -	12:00 am suddenly felt tired went to bed -	12:20 woke up because of nightmare -	Headache / Right shoulder hurts / couldn’t stand still   -	Probably pulled a muscle -	When to Kent County Hospital  August 10, 2005 - Kent County Hospital -	Head CAT scan (Brain) – findings no midline shift / no intracranial hemorrhage / no hydrocephalus / visualized sinuses are well aerated. Reported by DR.  MILLER (M.D) -	Lumbar (SPINAL TAP FLUID) Puncture – Findings : none -	Released w/o explanation  August 13, 2005 – Warwick Medical Walk-In -	Dr. Chang -	Headache like no other like 20X of migrane -	Butalbital w/ aspirin and caffeine -	Headache went away  August 14, 2005 – South County Hospital -	Couldn’t stay still (Nerves was up) -	Palpitation -	Dehydration -	Tested for Lyme disease -	Advised to stop taking Butalbital -	Diagnose with Post Concussion Syndrome / ANXIETY -	CAFFEINE Allergy -	Vicodin (5mg), Motrin 600 mg, Lorazepam 1 mg -	Stated Drinking DOXYCYCLINE 100mg (Prescribe by : Dr. Chang) to treat lyme disease  August 22, 2005 - MIDLAND MEDICAL Walk-In (Cranston) -	Check up / Follow up -	Feeling tired all the time -	Right shoulder /  hand  / foot feeling numbness -	Diagnose with vertical vertigo (Fingers press down on shoulder) -	Referred to Chiropractor  August 24, 2005 – DR. CALIRI (Warwick) -	Heaven and hell begins -	XRAY of bones -	Found out that my Spinal Cord is not sea shell form but SNAKE form -	Begin Pinching of the nerves -	Straightening Spinal cord -	Aligning of short leg  -	Aligning of neck because of accident -	For 2-4 Hours I feel nothing but after everything is contracting -	Muscles, nerves, everything -	I felt HOT and Cold at the same time but no fever -	ICEPACK is the only advised medicine -	2 weeks of Agony and then finally I stopped the sessions  because I couldn’t take the pain anymore.  -	It’s seems like it was adding more pain to my headache. -	STOPPED MEDICATION as well.  September 19, 2005 –STILL RECOVERING -	Need Second opinion because -	Still gets Headache (not severe) from -	RIDING CARS / WALKING / LOOKING DOWN / UP / WATCHING MOVIES / USING COMPUTER / MOVING FROM SIDE TO SIDE (NECK) -	Not taking any medicine but Ibuprofen -	Sometimes vision is hazy and dizzy  -	At the end of the day my head feels heavy, neck pain, back shoulder pain -	Where is the headache coming from? -	How long is Post concussion syndrome normally? -	How do you deal with anxiety when it attacks? -	Do I have a neck problem because of accident or Chiropractor? -	Am I still dehydrating? -	Do I need MRI? -	Will my Vertical Vertigo go away? -	Do I need Therapy? -	Am I heading for a stroke, blood clot, Artery block? -	WILL IT EVER GO AWAY or is this permanent?  I JUST TURNED 33 TWO WEEKS AGO... PLEASE I NEED HELP...

author: Dr. L. Chu Go  Medical Doctor Posts: 41 Joined: Fri May 27, 2005 9:08 am Location: Philippines  Contact:   Contact Dr. L. Chu Go       Yahoo Messenger
title: Re: Headache
content: Hello sososcared,  Are these headache attacks frequently occuring for the past week? if so, how frequent? Aside from the pain, do you also get photophobia (i.e. when exposed to bright lights, headache gets worse)? is this being triggered by your work load? any stressors both at home and at work? may I ask how old you are? do you have hypertension or any other underlying illness? Is there any numbness you feel aside the radiating pain?Based on the data you have just posted, it may just be a tension headache you are suffering from.. however, there are other factors we have to consider too which is why I have asked several other questions which will somehow help your physician when you go for your next visit. If your headaches persist, you can take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs in the mean time (i.e. ibuprofen, mefenamic acid, paracetamol, aspirin) provided that you take any of these on a full stomach.  MD

author: Jackie E. Pool, LPN  Nurse Posts: 42 Joined: Fri Jul 08, 2005 4:46 pm Location: Central Alabama
title: [no title]
content: BigPaul, Have you ever been diagnosed with Anxiety Disorder? Your symptoms sound very indicative of this.The headache you have could very well be from tension, keeping your shoulder muscle tensed up without being aware you are doing this, staying in a hieghtened state of anxiety.  Anxiety can cause many symptoms such as dizzines, heart racing, sweating, problems with sleep, headaches, feelings of fear( usually described as impending doom), add those together and you will usually come up with a Panic attack.  I would suggest you make an appointment with your PCP and have Complete Metabolic Profile done, just to make sure there are no imbalances. If all is normal range, ask your doctor about an anti-anxiety medication. There are many excellent ones on the market.  Hope all goes well with you.

author: Cassandra  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Tue Aug 30, 2005 12:01 pm Location: Albany, NY
title: Chronic headache, some nauseau, pressure
content: For a month, I have been struggling with a chronic headache.  It came on suddenly, felt like severe pressure in my head.  I've had migraines before, and this didn't feel like those at all, and none of my migraine meds touch it.  After several days, I happened to have my blood pressure checked, and it was 198/105, had never had high BP before.  They put me on BP drugs (I'm 52 yrs) which made my head feel less like it was going to explode, but the pain continues - sometimes sharp driving pain at the temples or center of my head, much stiffness in the neck area, and a foggy, full feeling in the head in general. Sometimes it ebbs a bit, but never leaves.  I've had some nausea with this, dizziness, breathlessness as well.  The only other thing I've noticed with it is fluid retention, not sure in the chicken-and-egg debate if that's coming first or not.    Even codeine/tylenol combos don't help, tried chiropractic, anti-anxiety, nothing.  They did an MRI, was normal; ran bloodwork; put me on antibiotics in case there was sinus involvement - nothing is working.  Have a neurologist appointment in a few weeks, also going for a 24-hr urine scan to explore kidney involvement.  With the BP meds, the BP is generally 130/100.  It's getting very tiring, really limiting what I can do - hard to concentrate, work.  Any help would be MUCH appreciated - thank you.

title: Athlete with severe SINUS-type headaches
content: I would greatly appreciate a Doctor's insight on my headache problems.  I am a 22-yr. old female- I have been an athlete all my life and run quite a bit. I have been to a general physician as well as an ENT----but neither Dr. had any explanation for what could be causing the headaches.  They come very sporadically- sometimes months apart.  When it happens, I will wake up with my head throbbing and the headache won't go away for 2-3 days. The pain is always behind my eyes, and sometimes in a band across my forehead.  I have no allergies and don't get sick very often. I sleep alot, eat healthily and exercise everyday.  I don't smoke, take meds, etc.  The only medicine that has worked even partially is Sudafed Sinus Headache- however I hate being dependent upon this medicine.  Can you please give me some advice as to what this might be caused by, or what type of specialist I might go see?

author: Dr. R. Perala  Medical Doctor Posts: 12 Joined: Tue Aug 09, 2005 6:02 pm Location: Cave Creek, Arizona  Contact:   Contact Dr. R. Perala       Website
title: [no title]
content: Hi:  This doesn't sound like the typical migraine headache, but it may be an unusual form.  In medicine there is a saying:  "Unusual presentations of common diseases are more likely than classic presentations of uncommon diseases."  And, I think what this may be is an unusual migraine.  Migraines tend to present at around age 22 and they are 3x more common in females than males.  They are unique in that they may awaken you from sleep and they are characteristically described as "throbbing" headaches.  Most migraines are on one side of the head (the word migraine comes from "hemi-crania" (half the head), which was pronounced "hemi-grania" in middle english and was later shortened to migrania or migraine).  However, I have seen more migraines than I can count that affect the whole head or just the front, like yours.  It is *extremely* common for migraines to be confused with sinus headaches.  I've even seen Sudafed partially relieve migraine headaches (the main ingredient in Sudafed is pseudoephedrine, which can be vasoactive...That is, it can counter the vasodilatation that is thought to produce pain in migraines).  This is probably more detail than you need!  The bottom line is this:  See a neurologist!  If you've seen an ENT and a CT of your sinuses came back clean (or at least not suggestive of severe chronic sinusitis), then your next step would be to see a neurologist.     If you get a chance to post back on the forum, let me know if you have any other symptoms with your headaches...Do you have any nausea or upset stomach with your headaches, or even just loss of appetite?  Does noise or bright light bother you during your headache?  Does moving around a lot exacerbate the headache pain?   "Auras" are actually pretty rare with migraines, but some people will see "moving spots before their eyes" before the headache starts...Do you ever experience anything like that?  Do you notice that disrupting your sleep schedule or skipping a meal gives you a headache?    Hope this helps!  -Reid
posted_time: Post  by Dr. R. Perala » Sat Sep 03, 2005 1:23 pm

content: On Aug. 18th I had a spinal block for a c-section and developed a terrible headache upon returning home from the hospital. It has been 5 days since the patch and I have spend a majority of this time laying down in hopes of this healing on its own.  I am wondering what are my treatment alternitives? I have accessed several sites that have said a second blood patch is often successful. What do you think?
posted_time: Post  by wle12160 » Mon Sep 05, 2005 11:56 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi wle12160, A second blood patch would certainly be something that you should discuss with your physician. Sometimes the first blood patch is unsuccessful and a second one is required. This more often than, not solves the problem, and rarely is there a need for more than two. If you do indeed decide to have this procedure repeated, the recommendation is to lay flat for approximately four hours and no lifting or overexertion for at least 48 hours. Again discuss this with your physician. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear future rn,  Your husband is suffering from something called Temporal (Giant cell) arteritis. It's a systemic vasculitic diease(inflammation in the arterial vessels) ...Usually starts as you've described your husband's symptoms and it gets elicited by combing the hair. It affects the jaw as well in the form of claudications,sometimes associated by headaches,mailaise,fatigue ,visual disturbances,etc.  Temporal artery biopsy is the criterion standard for diagnosing temporal arteritis. This procedure may be performed by ophthalmologists, general surgeons, head and neck surgeons, plastic or vascular surgeons, or dermatologic surgeons. With a positive predictive value of greater than 90%, temporal artery biopsy stands out as the definitive test for temporal arteritis.  He will be treated as an autoimmune disease...and should be treated for as soon as possible after obtaining the biopsy result, because it can lead to damage of his temporal artery and progression of the disease into other atreries,hence it's a systemic vasculitis disease. But once he's under treatment ,he will be more comfortable and controlled. All he'll be needing is follow up as with any other simple diseases,  Best regards,

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: Yes, you must see a specialist for the lingering symptoms.   In sinusitis, patients typically experience headache, purulent nasal drainage and pain over the frontal bone, at the bridge of the nose, and in the maxillary region. You clearly state that you have none of the symptoms.  In some cases of bacterial meningitis, the bacteria can spread directly to the meninges from a severe nearby infection, such as a serious middle ear  infection or a nasal sinus infection.(sinusitis). So, meningitis can be a complication of sinusitis.  As I stated in my first post,  it is better to be safe and exclude the sinister possibilities. Get to see a specialist, especially as the symptoms are persistent.  Meanwhile,  this post may be helpful : http://www.doctorslounge.com/forums/vie ... highlight=    Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi vman1616, I am not one of the doctor's but I will try to give you an answer without a slap in the head lol. Symptoms of brain tumors (benign or malignant and depending on the area of the brain affected) may cause balance problems, nausea and vomiting, speech problems, visual disturbances, hearing problems, seizures, etc., etc., and the headaches may be rather severe. I would consider some of the more common causes of a headache first. Tension and stress cause significant headaches. Certain foods, caffiene intake, dehydration, sinus infection, allergies, visual problems (change in sight-prescription change for glasses, the need for glasses), elevations in blood pressure, etc. etc. Multiple disorders cause headaches, I would suggest a vision exam to rule out and visual changes as well as a general physical exam by your physician to rule out any anomalies and assure the headaches are related to tension and stress. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: RobertL  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Mon May 02, 2005 12:01 am
title: Mixed Tension Migraine; been diagnosed, but unsure.
content: Alright, this all started last thursday; I started having pain behind my eyes, regular pre-migraine symptoms really.  It lasted till sunday, where it turned into a unbearable pain on the left side of my head.  My father (a doctor who specializes in rehabilitation) suggested I take some Advil.  Well, we didn't have Advil in the house, so he just gave me some Ibuprofen instead.  The pain quickly disappeared, but what remained was this painless pressure around my head that would move around different sides of my head.  It seemed to stay really on the top though.  I was of course worried, mainly because I'm not accustom to feeling any sort of pressure or pain in my head; at most I get 2 to 3 headaches a year.  The pressure was soon accompanied by his more annoying friend dizziness.  Because of this, I expected the worse.  My father said he wasn't exactly sure what it was, but he expected a migraine.  So, he told me to go into work with him the next day and he'll take me to see a neurologist.  I got no sleep that night because I was so worried about this painless heaviness/pressure in my head.  Well, I may have gotten atleast 3 to 5 hours worth of sleep, who knows...I just remember being so damn worried.  Anyway, I went into see a neurologist; he said everything looked normal, but sent me to get an MRI and blood work.  Now, I didn't get the blood work done, because my father said I didn't need it since I had it done about a month ago by that time.  I didn't know what the big deal was with getting the blood work done over a months span, but I was too worried about my head to care, so I went with him.  By the time I got the MRI, it had been roughly 16 to 20 hours since this painless pressure showed up.  The very next day, my father read the results from the report the neurologist had sent to him.  He said everything looked fine, but you have a slight sinus infection.  Alright, so maybe this is a sinus infection I thought.  I waited until my father came home that night; time seems so slow when you are so worried and anxious about something for the record.  When he arrived, the first thing I asked was, "So is this a sinus infection?"  His response, "Sinus infections don't occur on the top of your head, and you don't sound stuffed up.  I don't know what it is you have."  You can only imagine how worried I was after I heard these uncomforting and unassuring words.  So that night I had trouble sleeping, then again, I always have had trouble sleeping considering I have insomnia.  So, a day went by, the painless and sometimes slightly painful pressure was still there and even heavier; the eye pains had left though, but my vision was still a little blurred, and a new nasty symptom had hopped into the picture: nausea.  Oh, by this time it is wednesday already, for whoever is reading this.  At this point, I had noticed a consistant routine with this worrisome head pain/not pain: I would wake up, the pressure wouldn't be there up till 30 minutes to an hour, it would show signs of stopping during the day, but tease me by coming back, and when I would take my Clonodine for sleep time, it would turn faint.  This seemed to be the pattern with this undiagnosed thing.  I went to my father, complained about it, he gave me another one of his "I don't know what it is", so I asked him if I could see the neurologist the next day.  I went with him to work the next day (its Thursday again, oh boy!), saw a different neurologist (the other one was out of town, but they all work together in a cozy little office), fed him the details with my father there; he diagnosed it as a mixed tension migraine.  Now I will admit, I am a pretty unactive person, am overweight, and don't exactly eat healthy, which I understand does contribute to mixed tension migraines.  I don't know why though, but he then had me walk in place with my eyes closed, touch his fingers, but didn't do that light and magnifying glass thing in my eye like the last neurologist did though; for some reason that worried me, but I just kept my mouth shut and looked at his diplomas and awards on the wall.  Anyway, he then proceeded to tell me I was overweight (your a genius, doc), and went on and on, I think about 30 minutes, on how I needed to excersize more, eat right, be lessed stressed out and anxious, and this thing would go away.  Alright, done.  At the time, this mixed tension migraine had disappeared and remained faint for about 3 hours of the whole day.  But, by the next day (Friday) it had disappeared and remained faint for atleast 6 hours of the whole day. During the day at some point I decided to go outside for a 2 hour walk with my friend; the pressure was faint, and my vision was still a little spotty and blurry, but I went on like a trooper.  Before I went to sleep that night, the pressure had completely disappeared, but I still had trouble sleeping (I need to up my Clonodine; it seemed like I hadn't gotten any sleep at all that week.)  So, it's now Saturday,  I went to the pool for the first time in 3 years with some friends, went on an hour walk, and ate out for dinner.  I guess you could say I'm taking somewhat of the doctor's advice.  Oh, and the pressure is now pretty faint, but there's some flashes of pain here and there on different sides of my head.  Now, the reason I posted this: Is it normal for mixed tension migraines to be painless?  If they aren't supposed to be painless, is it possible that the MRI couldn't pick up on something that was undetectable at the time? And if it is a mixed tension migraine, will it be something that will remain with me for the rest of my life?  Sorry for the incredibly long post, but I'm still a little worried and uneasy about this, and would really appreciate a response as soon as its possible.  Thanks in advance.
posted_time: Post  by RobertL » Sun Jun 26, 2005 1:12 am

author: stephanie0107  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Sun Jun 26, 2005 1:18 am Location: United States  Contact:   Contact stephanie0107       AOL
title: Migraines
content: Hello Friend, Migraines definitely not fun. It does not sound like you have prolonged history of migraines, so I am thinking may be r/t your HTN (high blood pressure) and/ or stress related. If you had MRI, you can feel confident that you don't have a brain tumor( if you should ever have seizure, in additon to migraines, brain tumor must be ruled out) however, still strange with the recent onset and minimal history of migraines, also you are a male? Females are more likely to get chronic migraines.  Any recent  life changes or new medications?  Is you HTN under control?  Also, any chance you were drinking red wine which may have promoted the migraines? (Tannins <stems, grape skins, twigs, etc..> in the red wine are notorious for certain individuals in causing headaches) or consuming cheese, chocolates, dairy products? Any history of migraines in your family? Change of climate, new onset of stress or worries? You mentioned nausea, did you vomit, if so, did it cure the migraine? Since you are under the care of a physician, you should trust in his judgement. Wouldn't hurt to have blood drawn again for complete work-up if the problem persists. Otherwise, keep a diary of any preceeding factors, foods, drink, stress, anything you think may be relevant. Keep an eye on your BP, get one of the do it yourself automatic monitors available at any pharmacy and keep a log of you pressure when a migraine comes on. Any visual disturbances? May just need to adjust dose of your meds. Also, might ask you dr for rx for Imitrex or Relpax, many other non-narcotic great meds these days depending on if you have them on occasion (1-2x/mo) or frequent and need daily preventative meds. No need to live with migraines, also some have luck with herbs. If you feel one coming on, be sure to get to a quiet, dark, peaceful location and wait it out if tolerable. Hope this helps. Good luck.
