author: stephanie0107  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Sun Jun 26, 2005 1:18 am Location: United States  Contact:   Contact stephanie0107       AOL
title: Migraines
content: Hi Robert,  Yes, these type of migraines can be accompanied by "painless pressure", although that in itself can be very distracting and annoying. As far as family history, migrraines have high occurance of familial origin, so if adopted, might just assume yes. If these only continue to affect you several times a yr, consider yourself very lucky indeed and just treat them as they occur. Take a day or two off work if possible, rest, rx prescribed by your dr. Really, if only occuring on rare occasion, I wouldnt even waste time trying to pinpoint what precipitates them since this can be uncertain. Good that your BP is ok, follow your dr's advice and eat healthy, mild exercise, etc. This is not just for your migraines, but all around well being and hopefully to minimize migraine occurance.  Most of all, if you have a sudden onset migraine accompanied by visual disturbances, make sure to stop what you are doing, esp if driving and get to a cool, dark, quiet location and rest for several hours. Have your prescription on stand by and administer as directed. Like I stated previously, much medical research and advances have been made in this field and immediate rx injections or p.o. (by mouth) should readily alleviate an unexpected attack. Some sufferers experience "auras" and are able to predict an oncoming attack, so, if your attacks increase or are incapacitating in nature, keep a diary and discuss with your physician. Most common aura is visual in nature or ringing in ears. Just make an attempt to be in touch with your s&s (signs & symptons) and you can actually get to the point of warding off a full migraine attack altogether. Much luck. Please let me know how you are doing and if you need any additional info.

title: Reoccuring headaches, now unrelated dizzyness
content: Hello, I have been having very bad headaches for about four years now.  They started to happen four years ago, with very little frequency.  And over the last four years they have begun to happen more and more.  Now to the point where, over the last few months, they have been happening almost every day.   Also, today, while I was driving to work, a sudden spell of dizzyness came upon me.  It was very bad, to the point that I was not safe driving.  The dizzyness was not related to a headache of any kind this morning (that is why I am ruling out the migrane style of dizzyness). My headaches are pretty severe sometimes, and sometimes they are just annoying.  But they are now regular, almost every day.  When they first started, I began taking Exedrin Migrane.  That has seemed to help make them go away.  Now the Exedrin doesn't work anymore.   If anyone has any ideas as to what is causing all of this, or what I can do to make it stop, please tell me.  My wife is getting worried about me!  Thank you so much. Ryan

author: Lisa K, RN  Nurse Posts: 36 Joined: Fri May 20, 2005 10:20 am Location: Canada
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  I didn't read anywhere in your post that you've seen a doctor about your headaches/dizziness.....that would definitely be a good place to start.  Provide a good clear history of when the headaches started, how they've increased in frequency, what you take for them, the dizziness.  If a person has unusual symptoms that are becoming worse or increasing in frequency, it's your body's way of telling you you need to get things properly checked out.  When's the last time you had a complete physical?  If it's been a while, schedule an appt for one soon.    How is your blood pressure?  Have you had it checked regularly over the last 4 yrs?    What age are you?  Do you have any problems with your vision, particularly when you have the headaches? (blurred, double)

author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: Elley, you really need to get treated for whatever infection is causing your swollen gland.  The headache sounds like a migraine.  They are usually at the temple and/or behind the eye, even in the neck.  If you don't have a history of ulcer, try taking excedrin - tylenol and advil won't work; excedrine has some caffiene, aspirin and tylenol all together.  The key ingredient is caffeine.   The earlier you treat the headache, the better success you will have.

author: jamielynn  Guest Posts: 8 Joined: Mon Apr 25, 2005 12:17 pm Location: Alabama
title: Getting Frustrated Please Help!!!!!!
content: Hey, I am a 25 year old female with no major medical problems but for the past four months i have been having all of these symptoms that the doctors can not find any reasons that could be causing them. I'll start from the beginning. Jan. 15 - I went to doctor with a headache. I have experienced migraines before but this was different woke one morning with a headache and it never went away for two weeks. I was diagnosed with tension migraine headaches given anti-inflammitories and muscle relaxers and told to see a physical therapist for the immobility of my neck. After three weeks of therapy and things getting worse I went back to doctor who suspected a pinced nerve in my neck and sent me to a neurologist.   By this time, my right hand had become completely numb. After an MRI of my neck and nerve conduction studies of my hand, there was no pinched nerve. After blood tests were done by neurologist and an MRI of my head, nothing was shown except an elevated blood platelet count. Right hand still numb and weak and beginning numbness in my right leg.   The neurologist referred me to a hematologist for more blood tests. My platelets are still elevated and now I am experiencing complete numbness in my leg and weakness (hard to walk sometimes) I also experience cold fingers on my right hand while my left hand will be completely warm. I have been told to take a low-dose asprin everyday to reduce my chance of blood clots since I already have high cholesterol. And just this week I have been experiencing severe itchiness all over my body. I am not currently on any medicine except asprin and have no known things that Ii am allergic to. Could someone offer me any explanation?   Doctors just keep saying we don't know lets run more tests. I'm beginning to feel like they think I'm making it all up. Which is not the case, I hate going to doctors and hate blood tests but I continue to go and do all the tests because something may it be minor is truly wrong with me. Please help!!!  Jamie

title: Neck pain and Unilateral Headache.
content: I am a 23 year old white male.  5'11''  320 lbs - Blood pressure slightly high.  Not taking any medications, no other medical conditions except infrequent migraines that are not unilateral.  I recently started experiencing constant neck pain and a unilateral headache both varying in intensity.  The pain ranges from mild discomfort to a throbbing/pounding/tense pain.  The best way to describe the pain would be a feeling of pressure and pain traveling from my carotid artery where i check my pulse on the left side of my neck, up behind my ear, to my temple, and when most severe extending to the entire left side of my brain.  Occasionally i have the sensation of muffled hearing or ringing in my left ear associated with this.  A couple times I had a feeling of foggy light headedness or what some call "medicine head".  It's now the 4th day and what I initially thought was caused by sleeping with my neck in a bad position has me a little more concerned.  Due to the fact that I do not have health insurance, I am trying to find out if this is a potentially serious problem that I should seek treatment for or if I should give it a few more days.  Any suggestions about what this may be would be very much appteciated.  Thanks! -Ryan

author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: Sleeping wrong would probably not cause this type of unilateral headache.  Migraines are more often than not unilateral.  Are you having the sensitivity to light/sound?  Having any nausea?  There is no guarantee that it is a migraine, however.  It could definitely be a more serious neurological abnormality.  You have waited four days already, you should not wait any longer - your health is more important than some money.

content: For over 2 years I have had the same problem. For almost 2 years I have been to my doctor, other doctors, eye doctors, have been on various medications and have had numerous tests all unconclusive.  I have pressure that seems to be behind my eyes and in my forehead constantly. I feel light-headed, off balance, dizzy. Every day I have to fight with my eyes. My eyes get a "pull" to them. If you make yourself look cross-eyed...that's what my eyes do but by themselves whether I'm looking straight ahead or off to either side. Once my eyes just voluntarily crossed but when I looked in the mirror my eyes were facing straight. Just a couple of days ago I looked at something to the side of me and both my eyes pulled. Sometimes I get blurred vision and spots all the way around my pupil but I can see fine through the middle. This always last anywhere from 20 minutes to an hour and sometimes more than once a day. I always feel a headache and pressure but more so before and especially after my eyes do that. I also get headaches after I eat. I have had an MRI, cat scan, sinuses ex-rayed, have been on migraine medication (which only made me feel worse), ulcer, blood and allergy tests, my eyes were dialated as well as other tests and medications.   The only diagnosis that came over the last 2 years is my cholesterol and sugar is a little high.  I watch what I eat and exercise at least 4 times a week. When I was 14 or so I had an operation for scoliosis.  Could the harrington rods and wires in my back have anything to do with the way I feel now?  I've been fine for over 20 years physically except for back pain and muscle stiffness from the surgery I imagine. At this point I don't know what kind of physician or treatment to seek.

author: crowan1984  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Wed Apr 27, 2005 10:50 am Location: Columbus, Ohio
title: I hope this helps
content: I was having a similar problem, except that I was getting blurry vision and some double vision.  I went to an opthamologist to check my eyes that said I had a little hemmoraging on my optical nerves.  I had a cat scan, and 2 mri's one for my head and one for my eyes (orbits).  they showed no masses, but I was still having headaches.  I then was sent to a neuro-opthamologist that told me I was having these headaches due to high spinal/brain fluid pressure.  They did a lumbar puncture (a form of spinal tap) to measure the opening pressure.  I was told that a 20 was normal and I had a 47.  So they drained fluid.  I am not sure if this helps or not, but you may want to ask your doc about it.

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Dear kimberly629: You have listed several contributing factors to headaches.  First of all smoking decreases the amount of oxygen that gets to your brain by constricting the blood vessels, this in turn can cause you to develop headaches.  You did not say how much overweight you are.  A person who is obese can develop sleep apnea which is the stopping breathing for a short periods of time while  you are sleeping.  This causes a person to not get adequate rest.  It also causes mouth breathing during sleep which can contribute to both nasal congestion and headaches.  When you don't rest well, you can develp muscle tension and aches and pains.  Sleep apnea can also lead to heart failure so it is not something to ignore.  Of more immediate concern is the "almost blacking out when standing up". When a person stands the blood, that has pooled while they were sitting down, rushes into their lower extremities thereby lowering their overall blood pressure.  If their blood pressure drops too low, they black out or faint.  This is serious and needs to be checked out by a doctor.  Quitting smoking and losing weight will benefit you all around but that all takes time.  Right now you need to find out what is causing your blood pressure to drop suddenly when you stand up.  I urge you to see your doctor right away.  Please let me know how you are doing.  I care. Kind regards, Carolyn
posted_time: Post  by Carolyn Merritt, LPN » Mon Mar 14, 2005 3:52 pm

title: Severe head and eye pain when flying
content: When flying recently, as we were preparing to land, I experienced a sudden severe stabbing like pain in left eye.  Of all my previoius migraines, this was the worse pain I've ever experienced and it was very frightening.  My eye began tearing up and I had to apply pressure to my eye and forehead.  It's been 10 days and my left eye is still very sore near eyebrow.  I've had 3 migraines since the flight and it has been years since I've had one.  I'm due to fly again next week and I'm extremely nervous.  I'm making an appointment with an opthamologist.  Any other suggestions?  Thanks so much.
posted_time: Post  by pburton » Sat Feb 12, 2005 6:24 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi pburton, Cluster headaches exhibit these symptoms. These occur once every day for a few days, weeks or months. Can occur at approximately the same time each episode. Very severe stabbing pain on one side of the head that usually lasts only one or 2 hours. Pain is usually centered on one eye, which often becomes watery and red. It is quite wise for you to be evaluated by your opthamologist to rule out an underlying eye condition especially if there are visual changes. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Whiney,  It is very unwise to wait for your doctor's appointment, which comes up in a week' s time.  Your symptoms of severe headache, neck pain and stiffness, profuse vomiting, fever and confusion are suggestive of raised intracranial pressure or meningeal irritation, which may result from a variety of sinister causes.  Please go immediately to ER for urgent investigation and care.  Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

author: stanster  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Thu Jan 06, 2005 5:24 pm Location: Texas
title: [no title]
content: Hi Jessica, I'm not a doctor. However, I would like to put my two cents in about headaches. I've had nagging headaches since I was a teenager (years now). I was diagnosed with migraines 10 years ago. I have done extensive research on different types of headaches and medicines used for them. The doctor has tried everything under the sun to help me cope. What I have found to be MOST useful in curbing the pain is: Taking 2 generic aspirins and melting them in a tablespoon with hot or warm water. This allows the medicine to be quickly absorbed into the blood stream once swallowed. I usually have to lay down in a quite/dark room for 30 minutes after taking the aspirins before the headche goes away. My point is, the melted aspirins have worked better than all of the prescription medications I've tried, and trust me, I have tried a bunch! Good luck to you. And again, this is what works best for ME.....SWT

author: Kazzy  Guest Posts: 18 Joined: Thu Oct 21, 2004 2:54 am Location: Australia  Contact:   Contact Kazzy       Yahoo Messenger
title: Migraine with sore slightly swollen neck
content: Hi,  Sorry this is so long but i figured you'd need to know a little of the history behind my problem if i'm going to get any possible answers.  I've not posted on this site before but thought i'd see if anyone can help? I've suffered from Migraines since i was in my teens but until recently have only occured about once a month. I also started suffering chronic sinusitis a few years back which didn't help. I had that opperated on last year.  Anyhow, about 10mths ago i had a migraine which passed late afternoon. Later that evening i started feeling very sick and felt like i was going to pass out. This lasted maybe 10 minutes before i DID pass out and was told that while i was out had a seizure. I had a CT scan done and EEG and both come back clear. Since then i've had a few near faiting spells (feel sick and like i'm going to faint but passes after couple of minutes). The headaches started getting a little worse but not until the last few months had i really noticed a huge difference in them. I've been getting Weekly migraines and almost daily headaches. There's very few days in the last few months where i've had no head pain at all. When i have a migraine during the worst of it my neck usually starts to ache but the last few weeks i've noticed that even without migraine my neck aches. Some of the migraines have started with an ache in my neck the seems to spread through the base of my skull right through the entire right side of my head. It's usually when the migraine is on the right side that my neck is worst (the neck pain is on the right side). I've noticed that just below my hairline on the right side there's some slight swelling and is quite tender. I've had full blood work done and thyroids are fine.  If anyone has any ideas what could be causing this and if i should be concerned could you please let me know.   Thanks tons and again sorry it was so long.  Kazzy
posted_time: Post  by Kazzy » Thu Oct 21, 2004 3:21 am

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  From your description, what comes to mind is what is known as Migraine Variant or MV. Seizures and strokes have been classified under this category. So, what happens here is, the patient with migraine may manifest with seizure even without epilepsy. Or another patient with migraine may manifest with paralysis even without a stroke. Since all your workup has so far resulted normal, I would consider these to be part of migraine.  Hope this helps.  bill

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: i only have the headache and neck ache
content: Dear Anit,  i think that this headache is related to your neck pain and once this neck pain is gone, the headache will be too hopefully.  If you are so worried about meningitis, i suggest that you be vaccinated against it especially if you are a new college student and live in the dorms now where there is lots of crowds. If you think at any time that you have been exposed to anyone who has meningitis, there is prophylaxis by you getting a certain antibiotic for a certain period of time.  If you think that this headache has anything to with meningitis, you have to seek medical attention immediately.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
